Children must never disrespect the lion or 'play with its name', or it will remember and teach them a lesson when they are adults on the hunting-ground.
What the lion did to Xwerri-kau; and what parts of game should not be eaten by little children

A full-grown Bushman, whom the narrator knew, punished by a lion for having eaten forbidden portions of the lions prey, as a child. Told by Dia!kwain (L V.-8. 4574-4617 1/2, 9. 4618, with notes upon 4616 rev. and 4617 rev.). |xam parents tell their children about what happened to Xwerri-kau, as a lesson about the eating of certain things: Xwerri-kau (who had eaten prohibited parts of game as a child) was pursuing a quagga when a lion sprang on him, and the quagga lay down to die once it saw that the lion had bitten him. This story illustrates how lions remember what children do and take revenge in various ways on the hunting ground when they are grown-ups. It also contains information about the hunting-ground.

A full-grown Bushman, whom the narrator knew, punished by a lion for having eaten forbidden portions of the lions prey, as a child. Told by Dia!kwain.(L V.-8. 4574-4617 1/2, 9. 4618, with notes upon 4616 rev. and 4617 rev.). An account of how a lion dreams and how it has the ability to make things obey their will (they 'work things').
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-9 or BC151_A2_1_058

Springbok will lead people to a lion. Their knowledge of distant things gained by their fine scent. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain, from his parents (L V.-9. 4619-4651). Also, game knows the time of men's deaths, and as such their behaviour must be observed. The springbok tells people things if they understand its actions.
The explanation of the name Ssu-!kui-ten-tta (or Snore-White-Lying)

note explaining the curious name of the son of a sorceress.(L V.-9. 4652 and 4651 rev.). The naming of the Bushman Ssu-!kui-ten-tta (or Snore-White-Lying or 'Witbooi'). [A] His mother 'snored' people without a kaross.
What the springbok and the gemsbok did when they knew that Dia!kwain's wife would die

Death of the narrators first wife, which was foretold by springbok and gemsbok. By Dia!kwain (L V.-9. 4653-4688). An account of what the springbok did when Dia!kwain's first wife (Mietje) died. Ssu-!kui-ten-tta points out that he had told Dia!kwain that the actions of the game foretold what was happening at home.

note respecting sorcerers who assume the shape of birds or jackals, on p.4701 rev.). [A]About '||khabbo's place' where sorcerers turn themselves into jackals if they want to kill people or birds, so as to fool people into thinking they are these animals.
The owl and the black crow

The Owl and the Black Crow foretell the approach of the Lion. By Dia!kwain (L V.-9. 4689-4706 1/2, 4696 rev., and 4697 rev.). Parents teach that when the owl screams and acts a certain way it means a lion is coming to take them in their sleep. The black crow also warns of the coming of the lion.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-10 or BC151_A2_1_059
The Bushman doctress and sorceress Ttanno !khauken

An old sorceress (a relative who befriended the narrators family), her power of turning herself into a lioness, her pet springbok, etc. By Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4707-4743). Dia!kwain's aunt, the sorceress Ttanno !khauken, changes herself into a lioness to see what her people are doing and to take care of them. Dia!kwain's father kills her short-horned springbok, but she is not angry even though it is not a food springbok, but a tame one (it was her 'heart's springbok').
Told in illustration of the picture of the dance of sorcerers (Mr Stow's number 8 and 9)
Remarks upon sorcerers, their dress, etc. (in explanation of one of Mr Stows copies of Bushmen paintings), by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4744-4750). ken.
Why Dia!kwain's brother Ko-bbo received his name

Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607). Dia!kwain's mother named his brother Ko-bbo because the people at their place blamed her family for all the misfortunes that occurred there. They called Dia!kwain's people 'Bbo' and threatened them. These same people killed Dia!kwain's grandmother and grandfather 'with sorcery' and intended to kill the rest of his family as well.
A great Bushman doctress and sorceress Ttanno !khauken who did not understand Dutch
More about the great sorceress Ttanno !kauken who did not understand Dutch: the parents taught the children to respect the great sorceress in many ways.
Names and information about Dia!kwain's brothers and sisters.

Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607). !kweiten ta ||ken is an 'orphan's name'.
The preparation of tinder from a certain thorn tree
The preparation of tinder. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.10. 4761 rev.4764 rev., note). Tinder-making, by |han=kasso (L VIII.-28. 8472 and 8473). !kou
The making of a needle from a springbok's foreleg
Why Dia!kwain's uncle |kai kwa received his name

Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607). The reason for the naming of Dia!kwain's uncle, |kai kwa.
The power over ostriches possessed by Dia!kwain's uncle, |uherre or 'Blaitje'

The power over ostriches possessed by /uherre (maternal uncle of Dia!kwain). This is followed by a long discourse concerning successful and unsuccessful hunting, as well as by a prayer, addressed by the mother of the narrator to the dead, that her husbands hunting might prove more fortunate. The result of this prayer is described. Allusion is also made to the belief that unsuccessful hunting may forebode danger to the hunter. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4778-4795-4868). Dia!kwain's uncle |uherre had in the past asked his spirit ancestors to give the people bad luck with the game because they had abused him. A man says that |uherre made an ostrich come to him, but complains that it is a lean bird. An old woman warns him that magicians first send lean, old and ugly things to test them. The people must eat the lean ostrich, after which fat ones will be sent to them. Dia!kwain's mother (and other women) beat the digging stone on the ground to pray to the spirit-people. The story moves on to a more general narrative about game-sorcerers and spirit-people.
The names for August and September were given by Dia!kwain, by whom it was also stated that the names for all the months are known to the old people. In the Katkop dialect (L V.-10. 4796).
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-11 or BC151_A2_1_060
How an owl (by its conduct) made |a-kkumm think that danger must be at hand and how she was sought for by a lion, which spoke to her in a man's voice

Dia!kwain's elder sister, |a-kkumm, comes upon an owl as she journeys from !kau-|nunu (Kenhardt) at sunset, and it behaves as if it is going to snatch her. When it leaves she is afraid because her mother had told her that when an owl leaves at sunset a beast of prey is near.
|nu-!ke or magicians who have died still possess power, and =kamme-an's prayer to them

The power of Game Sorcerers continues after death. Prayer addressed to them by the mother of narrator. (L V.-11. 4801 rev.-4809 rev.). Dia!kwain's mother tells of spirit-people who are dead game's sorcerers. The people do not see them but their sorcery is still around and they do not altogether die. There follows her prayer to the spirits of the sorcerers who formerly possessed game.

The Lion. Power over the time of sunset, and over the water-skins of the Bushmen, possessed by him. Flies tell him that a Bushman intends to fetch water, to-day. Caution in fetching water is recommended. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-11. 4869 rev.-4879 rev.). Dia!kwain's mother tells of lions and their doings when they want to catch and eat people. They make the sun set quickly to catch people out in the veld away from home and they make the waterskin tear .
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-12 or BC151_A2_1_061
The man who sought refuge from the rain in a cave, and found a lion there before him

The lion made the rain in order to confuse the man so he wouldn't know where his house was and the lion could catch him. The lion made it rain and waited in a cave for the man who sought refuge there.
The adventure of a girl, named Ttai-tchuen, with a lioness who had young cubs

Dia!kwain's cousin, Ttai tchuen, escapes from a lioness by remembering all the things her parents taught her about the doings of lions. She acts fearlessly and shines a button at the lioness to dazzle her and twirls around to scare her out of the den. Ttai tchuen leaves her mat behind so that the lioness will think it is her.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-13 or BC151_A2_1_062
The maiden who was taken up in a whirlwind by the agency of the angry Rain and became a great snake

The Maiden who would not listen to her parents, and was punished, together with those around her, by the angry Rain. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-13. 4981-5022). A story about the Early Race (the !khwe ||na ss'e !k'e) and the Rain, when the Porcupine was a man and how it came by the quills on its back and neck. The Porcupine's sister is a new maiden and behaves disobediently, and the Rain becomes angry and kills with lightning because it feels the girl does not protect the people. The brother must address the angry Rain in an effort to direct it to a different place. The new maiden is caught in a storm, even though she had been told not to go out. She is taken up by a whirlwind and becomes a snake.
How the brother of the maiden taken up in a whirlwind became the Porcupine; followed by various remarks about porcupines

The Young man (of the early race) who was changed into a porcupine. He is said to be the brother of the girl in the preceding legend. Remarks regarding the porcupine follow. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-13. 5023-5039, and 14. 5040-5054). A tale of the Early Race (or !khwe ||na ss'e !k'e) in which the brother of the maiden taken up in a whirlwind by the angry Rain is transformed into a Porcupine. Parents tell their children to avoid eating the back of the porcupine's neck and tail, because that is where the hail sits. Also about porcupines and the stars.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-14 or BC151_A2_1_063
How sorcerers sometimes assume the form of a jackal or of a bird; how they then act

The form of a jackal, or of a little bird, is sometimes assumed by friendly sorcerers.In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-14. 5055-5078 1/2 ). Sorcerers transform themselves into jackals and birds when they want to watch over their people who have moved away and whom they have loved. Wise people can tell when a bird is a sorcerer and tell him all is well.
How Xaa-ttin asked (or prayed to) the dead magician (named !nuin-|kui-ten) for rain, which was speedily bestowed

A dead Sorcerer, name !nuin|kuiten, asked by the narrators father for rain; which speedily came. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-14. 5068rev.-5078-rev.). Dia!kwain's father, Xaa-ttin, prays to his ancestor, the dead rainmaker !nuin-|kui-ten, for rain.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-15 or BC151_A2_1_064

The sorcerer !nuin|kuiten. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-15. 5079-5101, 5104-5109). The sorcerer !nuin-|kui-ten becomes a lion and goes about just to look at people, not to hunt them. !nuin-|kui-ten teaches Dia!kwain's father his magic because he feels that he is about to die.
The sorcerer !nuin|kuiten. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-15. 5079-5101, 5104-5109). A song sung by Xaa-ttin (Dia!kwain's father) after the death of the magician !nuin-|kui-ten.
What Xaa-ttin used to sing (the broken string)

The sorcerer !nuin|kuiten. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-15. 5079-5101, 5104-5109). A song that Dia!kwain's father Xaa-ttin used to sing: when he used to sleep he would hear a person calling him (the sorcerer !nuin-|kui-ten).
The dream which Dia!kwain had before he received the tidings of the death of his father

The dream of Dia!kwain, before he received news of his fathers death. Further omens, etc. In the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwain (L V.-15. 5110-5146). Dia!kwain dreams that he and his father are cutting up a sheep and a Dutch man ('Boer') threatens to beat them to death for killing the sheep. Dia!kwain awakes at daybreak and tells his wife that the dream had spoken like a person, of things that would come true. Dia!kwain's mother comes to tell him his father has died.
The relations of wind, moon, and cloud to human beings after death, etc. (L V.-15. 5147-5158). What happens when the |xam die.

The shade not to be sat in, unless it is really summer. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-15. 5149 rev. and 5150 rev.). Dia!kwain's mother told him what happens if one sits in the shade when the weather is not very hot.
A prayer addressed to the Moon, and another version of the Moon and Hare story

A version of the Moon and Hare story (which treats of the Origin of Death), preceded by a prayer, addressed to the young Moon. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-15. 5159-5168 1/2, 16. 5169-5198). A prayer to the new Moon and an account of the origin of death.
How to get rid of the evil influence of bad dreams

Mode of getting rid of the evil influence of bad dreams. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-15. 5160 rev.-5163 rev.). What Dia!kwain's mother did when she wished to get rid of the evil influence of bad dreams.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-16 or BC151_A2_1_065
How the approach of a commando is foretold by the mist

The near approach of a 'Commando' is heralded by a mist. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-16. 5199-5205). The |xam can tell when a commando is coming to attack them by the mist that comes in the morning.

About the Moon and death; good and bad moons; the stars also know things the people do not understand and the Moon sees things that will come to pass; if it is looked at, the Moon can allow game to live, even if the game has been poisoned or shot.
!ka !karro A small insect called , said to resemble the Moon, used by Bushmen women to ascertain if the men will bring food home
Moths coming to the fire of Bushmen by night foretell the killing of certain kinds of game
The coming of different kinds of moths to the fire at night foretells the killing of certain types of game. The moths resemble different types of game.
The coming of the Mantis [the mantis] to sit upon the quiver of the Bushman father at home foretells the shooting of a hartebeest

The |kaggen (or the mantis) that sits on the hunter's quiver foretells that the owner has successfully shot and killed a hartebeest on the hunting-ground. If the hunter's wife kills or drives away the |kaggen the hartebeest will recover and live because it, as well as the |kaggen, has not been respected. The game must be respected in order to kill it successfully.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-17 or BC151_A2_1_066
Words and sentences (and Dia!kwain's father's drawings)

rooi klip A series of six inserts on the inside cover of Book V-17 which contain brief references to falling stars, earthquakes and sorcerers, as well as some |xam names for certain animals. Reference is also made to the 'speech' of ants and there are a few lines about a 'tiger'. Most significantly, there is a note on drawings made by Dia!kwain's father on rocks and ostrich skins and the preparation of painting substances, such as (or red haematite).
About the hunting of game and the eating of flesh of certain game beforehand, such as eating slow-moving rather than fast game when going off to hunt.

The hunting of eland and related ceremonies. There are many things the hunter must do to show respect for the eland, as it is a 'magic thing' and |kaggen (the Mantis) will try to revive the game and keep it from dying. The verso notes contain further details of these practices. Pages 5359v-5361v contains warnings about the casting of shadows (translated by Dorothea Bleek).
The Mantis and the hunting of eland
What the |kaggen (Mantis) does to see whether the people respect the eland.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-18 or BC151_A2_1_067
Further ceremonies in cutting up eland
More ceremonies performed when cutting up eland, as it is a 'magic thing'.

Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607). Accounting for Dia!kwain's mother's 'little' name, which was |ko-an.
!num-!num About a moth called by the Bushmen and said to pour lice upon them
|goro A Bushman belief about a moth called , the coming of which to the fire at night foretells the slaying of an ostrich (or the finding of ostrich eggs) by one of the men
Successful Ostrich hunting foretold by the coming of a moth (Celna renisigma, Walker). In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-18. 5390-5405). goro,
The new maiden who ate the ostrich marrow from the thigh-bone of the ostrich without the knowledge of her people
A new maiden secretly eats the marrow from inside the ostrich's thigh-bone, although she is not supposed to.
Leopard hunting: the fatal adventure of !kwai-!kwa and his companion, and advice about leopard-hunting

A man called Gemsbok Leg, or !kwai-!kwa, goes hunting with a companion and they pursue a leopard that seems to disappear, but it has deceived them and is lying in wait. It kills !kwai-!kwa before he can warn his companion, who is also attacked.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-19 or BC151_A2_1_068
Jan Ronebout or =gerri-sse (at Breakwater and later at Mowbray)

Names of three Bushmen and another Native, who were at the Breakwater Convict Station in 1875, together with a little information regarding them. Taken down in English (L V.-19. 5445-5447, 5453-5456). =gerri-sse (Jan Ronebout) provides Lloyd with some personal details and the names of his closest relations (his mother, father and older brother Hendrik, who was also imprisoned at the Breakwater Convict Station). =gerri-sse's mother (!kwarra-an) was from ||kabbo's country and 'understood greatly'.
Jan Plat (at Breakwater; looked over later at Mowbray)

Names of three Bushmen and another Native, who were at the Breakwater Convict Station in 1875, together with a little information regarding them. Taken down in English (L V.-19. 5445-5447, 5453-5456). Jan Plat provides Lloyd with some personal details and the names of some of his closest relations, including his wife and parents. He was related to Dia!kwain (his wife was Dia!kwain's niece), grew up with Dutch people ('Boers') and understood |xam well.

Names of three Bushmen and another Native, who were at the Breakwater Convict Station in 1875, together with a little information regarding them. Taken down in English (L V.-19. 5445-5447, 5453-5456). =enn (Klaas Paai) provides Lloyd with some personal details and the names of some of his closest relations, including his wife and parents.
Thy name which is a Bushman name, what is it?'
Inquiry regarding name and dwelling-place. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-19. 5448-5452). Dia!kwain longs to hear the words of his own language.

Names of three Bushmen and another Native, who were at the Breakwater Convict Station in 1875, together with a little information regarding them. Taken down in English (L V.-19. 5445-5447, 5453-5456). Hendrik Ronebout (patient convict number 7910) provided these details of personal information while at the Breakwater hospital. He gave the names of his parents as well as details of where he came from.
Game once tame: why it grew wild

Dia!kwain's grandfather (!xugen-ddi) told him that game was once tame. The game acted as oxen do and allowed the people to stroke them, but a person called Chaser-of-food was in the habit of stroking the Quagga and then beating it, making it run away. Dia!kwain's grandfather was in the habit of frightening and beating away the game because he did not want the animals to stand still and be killed.

Falling Stars. Certain ceremonies in connection with them. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-19. 5478-5483, 5481 rev.,-5483 rev., note). At the death of a sorcerer, his heart falls (as a shooting star) out of the sky and goes into a water pit. The doings and power of sorcerers, etc. (L V.-19. 5483-5505). Falling stars go into the waterpit and sound like the rain; sorcerers' hearts also fall down from the sky and go into the waterpit with a thundering sound; the customs of sorcerers.
Bushman Presentiments, etc. A feeling which tells us something that happens in another place. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-19. 5504 rev., note).
About sorcerers: their death, their snoring work, earthquakes and the rain

Further details concerning what occurs at the death of a sorcerer, and concerning the harmful and beneficial doings of sorcerers (L V.-19. 5506-5530). When a sorcerer dies, an earthquake takes place, and a star shoots. Even when asleep, a sorcerer knows what is going about in the night; and takes care of the people, defending them from the sorcerers. (L V.-19. 5531-5536 1/2). Sorcerers' hearts sound like the rain when they die and their hearts fall into waterpits. Parents say they fear falling stars, because they know things that happen and always fall for a reason. Sorcerers can send their sorcery to different places to 'spirit' people away or kill them.

He changes himself into a jackal, and goes to find out what is detaining his people, when they do not return home. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-19. 5506 rev.-5512 rev.). Sorcerers' hearts become stars and come out of the sky when they die. In the form of a jackal, sorcerers seek people from their homes at night to see where they are and how they are doing.
Dia!kwain's explanation of the name which his mother gave him

Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607). Dia!kwain's explanation of the name his mother gave him after her family was roughly beaten by people who she thought showed no pity.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-20 or BC151_A2_1_069
Karosses must not be beaten upon the ground, for fear of bad consequences

What the Grass Bushmen do when angry. Karosses not to be beaten upon the ground, for fear of causing illness, and for fear of sorcerers. A way in which the latter cause illness is here mentioned. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (LV.-20. 5537-5556). Karosses are 'magic things' which must be respected. Sorcerers watch how people treat magic things and can kill those who do not show respect.
!kh'o The : a blue mist which resembles smoke
Brief mention is made of a kind of blue mist, which resembles fire-smoke, and is illness. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-20. 5557-5561). !kh'o
!ho, Dia!kwain's brother (Ko-boken) is standing up at dawn, despite warnings against doing so from his father. A little whirlwind, or comes and pushes him over and he staggers and has to lie down.

In a peculiar state of the atmosphere, in which sounds can be heard at a considerable distance, sitting, instead of standing, is recommended; for fear of evil consequences. Standing over those who are sitting, on account of its injurious effects, is also objected to, etc. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-20. 5559 rev.-5568 rev.). !ho

Gargling forbidden by the Bushman mothers, for fear of evil consequences. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-20. 5569 rev. and 5570 rev.). Children are not allowed to 'play' at gargling, although they may wash their throats if necessary.

Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607, translated). About Dia!kwain's father Xaa-ttin who received the name Clay-hand after he had an accident while running after springbok; he got his foot stuck in clay and fell, dislocating his thumb.

The Bushman names for a few Stones were given by Dia!kwain (L V.-20. 5574 and 5575), and by lhan=kasso (L VIII.-21. 7818, 7834). A list of the |xam and proper names of stones and gemstones, given by Dia!kwain at the Philadelphia Exhibition.
Parts of the ostrich not to be eaten by children

A certain portion of the Ostrich not to be eaten by children. In the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwain (L V.-20. 5573 rev. and 5574 rev.). ||xabbitten ||xabbitten ate the forbidden part of the ostrich and developed growths on his face afterwards.
The great Star !gaunu, which singing named the stars

The great star !gaunu, which singing, named the stars. By the position of certain stars, named by !gaunu, the porcupine knows the time for returning home. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-20. 5576-5580). The star !gaunu named small stars 'aquilae' - they influence the porcupine at dawn and are thus called the Dawn's stars.
The young man who was changed into stone, by the glance of a new maiden
A fragment of an account of a ceremony performed by Bushman maidens in order that their father's dogs should hunt well

A fragment, regarding the ceremony to be performed by the maiden, was also given by Dia!kwain (L V.-20. 5592 and 5593, translated, and 5591 rev., note). An account of the ceremony performed by a new maiden with her father's hunting dogs to protect them and help them hunt well.

Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607). An account of how Dia!kwain's brother-in-law, Mansse, was given the nickname of !kau |ho an, or 'Stone-knee', after he tripped and fell and cut his knee on a stone.
The girl who snaps her fingers at her parents and the rain
The rain is angry with us, if we talk to a maiden against her wish. (L V.20. 5608-5612). !kabbe'
The maiden who snaps her fingers at the rain (and causes lightning)

We should not allow a maiden to snap her fingers at us; the wrath of the Rain against us being thereby aroused. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-20. 5618-5622, 5624). An account of the maiden who snaps her fingers at the people, which makes the rain 'lighten' and try to kill them. The rain 'shoots' at the people when the girl shouts at them.
Dia!kwain plays the bow in a thunderstorm, or, The thunderstorm

!goura An account by Dia!kwain of the time that he played the while the rain fell and caused lightning at night. The rain struck them with lightning and they could not see and his mother tells him that the rain wants to kill them.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-21 or BC151_A2_1_070
Explanation of Mr G. Stow's pictures: 1 (habits of the hunting leopard)

Dia!kwain comments on George Stow's copy of a Bushman painting (no. 1) which features figures and various animals (numbered). He describes the doings of the |xam with regard to hunting. Dia!kwain goes on to describe the habits of the hunting leopard.
The Moon, not to be looked at, when game is shot

The Moon is not to be looked at, when game has been shot, for fear of evil consequences. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (LV.-21. 5643-5654). Hunters lower their heads and do not look up when they have shot game, because the Moon's 'water' would cause the game to live (the Moon's water is what the people observe lying on bushes, which resembles 'liquid honey').
Sneezing: to be avoided when game is shot

Sneezing to be avoided when game has been wounded. How to obviate the ill effect of a Sneeze. (L V.-21. 5654-5659). Mothers tell the children about how sneezing affects the death of game. Wounded game jumps up if the children sneeze.
Sneezing in the early morning considered to be unfortunate. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V. 21. 5654 rev. and 5655 rev., note). How to destroy a Sneeze. (L V.-22. 5658 rev., note). kkoroken

The Stars were formerly people. Some details regarding their singing. The opening of flowers from their buds compared with the former ways of the star. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L.V.-21. 5660-5668, and 5661 rev.-5663, rev., note). Stars resemble the Moon and used to be people. The stars resemble the budding flowers on trees. The stars burn like little fires.
A song sung by the star !gaunu, especially by the Bushman women

!gaunu is also !guonni and is at the bee's hole. He bewitches (or 'stabs') people (to death) if they go to the hole where he is. Dia!kwain says the fathers told them that !guonni is a 'thing' which 'pinches the chest' and knocks people down.
Stars and game behave in a similar way: when an animal is wounded the stars arouse its heart and make it want to walk.

Stones must not be thrown at the !kuerri-|nan (a little bird which is supposed to belong to the Rain). The evil effects of so doing exemplified in the case of the narrators cousin. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-21. 5698-5707). Children should respect swallows and not throw stones at them, for fear of being killed or made ill by sorcerers. Kki-a ||ken fainted and got ill after throwing stones at a swallow with some other little boys when he was a child.
Kki-a-||ken who threw stones at swallows
Regarding various Bushmen. Partly in English after and partly in Bushman (L V.-21. 5702 rev. and 5703 rev.). kku'obbo
The locusts (with the locust birds which accompany them) are set free by Sorcerers. Stones not to be thrown at the locusts. (L V.-21. 5708-5719 1/2). kerri
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-22 or BC151_A2_1_071

How to relieve a little child from the alarm caused by the sound of an earthquake. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-22. 5728-5735). Earthquakes happen at the time when sorcerers seek people to take away. Shadows must not fall on other people in the early morning because this is when invisible sorcerers can see people and stab them down.

The human heart is believed to fall down at death. A star likewise falls. (L V.-22. 5731 rev.-5733 rev., note). When people are about to die, their heart does not 'stand' as it did but falls like the star.
Explanation of Mr G. Stow's pictures: no. 2

An explanation of No. 2 of Mr G.W. Stows collection of copies of Bushman Paintings was given, in the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwain (L V.-22. 5739-5742). The painting features figures (numbered) and animals. Dia!kwain describes some of the hunting methods of the |xam.

The Rain Sorcerer, ||kunn. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-22. 5743-5754). ||kunn says that the people have spoken harshly to him, as if he really owned the rain. They scold him when it does not fall, but forget that they asked him for it when the rain does fall.
ken Mr G. Stow's picture no. 3 (the || dance)

The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (who may be of either sex.) By /han=kasso (L VIII.-20. 7757-7762, 7768-7774). Remarks upon sorcerers, their dress, etc. (in explanation of one of Mr Stows copies of Bushman paintings), by Dia!kwain. (L V.-10. 4750, 4755-4757.) A curious description of a dance and other doings of sorcerers was given in explanation of No. 3 of Mr Stows copies of Bushman paintings (L V.-22. 5755-5775). Further details regarding sorcerers (suggested by Mr J.M. Orpens copy of Bushman paintings - published in the for July, 1874.) were also given by Dia!kwain (L V.-25. 6008-6013). ken

The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (who may be of either sex.) By /han=kasso (L VIII.-20. 7757-7762, 7768-7774). Remarks upon sorcerers, their dress, etc. (in explanation of one of Mr Stows copies of Bushman paintings), by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4750, 4755-4757). A curious description of a dance and other doings of sorcerers was given in explanation of No. 3 of Mr Stows copies of Bushman paintings (L V.-22. 5755-5775). Further details regarding sorcerers (suggested by Mr J.M. Orpens copy of Bushman paintings - published in the for July, 1874.) were also given by Dia!kwain (L V.-25. 6008-6013).

Death. The stars know the time at which a Bushman dies, and the fall of one announces, to those who are not aware of it, that something bad has happened. When, after this, a 'Hammerkop' (Scopus umbretta), flies, calling out over the Bushmen, the people know that someone belonging to them has died. Girls who have been killed by lightning are changed into stars. Girls who have been taken away by the water become like a beautiful water-flower, which will not allow itself to be plucked, and disappears when approached. Such flowers must be let alone. The place in the sky in which lightning appears should be looked at, so that the lightning may not kill us by stealth. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-22. 5776-5809).
Concerning apparitions (or How, when the first wife of Dia!kwain was buried, those returning to their homes saw the apparition of a little child)

Apparition seen by the party returning from the burial of the narrators wife; followed by the account of an apparition seen, on another occasion, by the narrators brother-in-law. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-22. 5810, 23. 5811-5832). Dia!kwain and his people were returning from burying his wife when they saw an apparition that resembled Dia!kwain's wife. He believed it to be something that appears at the time when sorcerers take people away. Dia!kwain's brother-in-law, Mansse, also saw an apparition on the hunting-ground. Apparitions resemble people in some ways, but are also different.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-23 or BC151_A2_1_072
Custom observed with Bushman children, when too young to walk

A ceremony performed with the Brachycerus (African Ground Weevil) in order to preserve young babies from convulsions. In the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwain (L V.-23. 5833-5840). The Brachycerus used to cure illness in little children. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-21. 7822-7825).
The crying of the wind is an evil omen
The crying of the Wind believed to forebode evil. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-23. 5841-5845).

A certain old woman named /xannan-/xannan, who had power over the wind. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-23. 5842 rev., 5845, 5845 rev. and 5846 rev.). The protection extended by the Wind to /xannan-/xannan. (L V.-23. 5862-5871). About the old woman called |xannan |xannan (or =na a -an) and what she did with the wind when the people scolded her and made her angry. Dia!kwain's grandfather would ask |xannan |xannan to open her kaross so that the wind would blow out of it and blow away the mosquitos which kept him awake at night.
The crying of the wind tells beasts of prey where to find people

The crying of the Wind tells the beasts of prey where to find people, and when it blows strongly they can approach the dwelling unheard, etc. (L V.-23. 5846-5857). People must hide when the wind blows strongly, as it means that the lion is coming for them and the blowing hides the sound of its approach from the dogs.

Resemblance between /xannan-/xannan and an ostrich. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-23. 5858-5862). The son of /xannan-/xannan. (L V.-23. 5860 rev. and 5861 rev.). The old woman |xannan |xannan did not resemble other people: she resembled an ostrich and also walked like one. She lived at the Sak River with Dia!kwain's people, where he observed her actions firsthand.
Jan Plat's story about his brother Ruyter

Information regarding the family of 'Jan Plat' (a mixed Namaqua Hottentot and Bushman) was taken down, in English, after Dia!kwain (L V.-23. 5872, 5871 rev. and 6872 rev., 25. 6006 rev., note). 'Ruyter' (a relative of the preceding). In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-23. 5873-5880). About the man called Ruyter (brother to Jan Plat); the names of his relations in |xam and Dutch and some details about them. Ruyter was brought up by white men and beaten to death by a Dutch man ('Boer') called Koos Struys who accused him of not herding sheep well.
About the Baboons and the Quagga, who were formerly people when those who are now people were not alive. Even though they are animals their organs still smell like they did when they were people.

The Bushmen are said to have learnt the =gebbi-ggu from the Baboons, by whom it is still believed to be played. It was formerly, it is said, played also by the Ostrich and the Lion; but they fought and lost the power of playing it, becoming merely wild animals. (On page 12 of Dr. Bleeks 'Second Report concerning Bushman Researches' (Cape Town, 1875), mention is made of a fable entitled, 'The Lion jealous of the voice of the Ostrich'.) In this piece, the above-mentioned quarrel between Lion and the Ostrich and the game of =gebbi-ggu is related. The Baboon, on the contrary, still understands like a man, and speaks, sounding like one. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-23. 5884-5890.) The =gebbi-ggu, as performed among the Grass Bushmen, was described by /han=kasso (L VIII.-22. 7978 and 7979). The Baboon taught the =gebbi-ggu in the earlier times when Lions and Ostriches sang the =gebbi-ggu along with the Baboon. Only the baboon still speaks and understands and sings the =gebbi-ggu, sounding like a man.
The adventure of |khui- |a with a family of baboons

|khui- |a is out hunting and shoots a mother baboon who is carrying a child. The father baboon goes to find the child and asks |khui- |a to leave it alone and not kill it, as he has already taken the baby's mother from him. |khui- |a is frightened and picks up his things and leaves them alone.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-24 or BC151_A2_1_073
Baboons should not be spoken with

Baboons not to be answered, when they address a Bushman in the early morning on his way to the hunting ground. They must, also, be alluded to in a very guarded manner, lest they should know that they are being spoken of. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-24. 5902-5910, 5905 rev. and 5906 rev., note). Baboons are not 'good people' and do not 'merely' want to sit and talk as people pass. The baboon gets angry and teases. It mocks and deceives people as they pass by.
Cuts to be made on a bow when a baboon has been killed

Certain cuts to be made upon the bow, when a Baboon has been killed. A similar ceremony to be observed with regard to the Hyena. A Baboon, when killed, resembles a man, in 'making cloud'. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-24. 5911-5916, 5911 rev., note). Dia!kwain's father told him that the baboon's bad influence, brought about by its death, would live on in (or curse) the bow if the bow was not cut, causing the influence to leave the bow.
Cuts to be made on a bow when a hyena has been killed

Certain cuts to be made upon the bow, when a Baboon has been killed. A similar ceremony to be observed with regard to the Hyena. A Baboon, when killed, resembles a man, in 'making cloud'. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-24. 5911-5916, 5911 rev., note). When a hyena has been killed, the bow is also cut with lines (as with killing a baboon) to remove the hyena's curse from the bow. This is so that the hyena's 'actions' will not be on the bow.
What is said to a person whose actions are disagreeable
What is said to people whose actions are disagreeable (or 'not nice'). The person is cursed and others are angry with him. The people question his treatment of them.
Baboons try to shoot people - means of preventing It

When shot, baboons will often try and throw the arrow back at the hunter and kill him too. When hunters see a baboon pull out an arrow and hold it in a certain way they must tell it that it is a 'girl's arrow', which will shame the baboon.
Baboons speak Bushman, and have wives

Baboons are said to speak the Bushman language and to possess wives. Their use of Sso|oa, which informs them of matters otherwise unknown to them. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-24. 5924-5926, 5923 rev.-5925 rev.). ss'o |a

The name of a Bushman seems to be known to a Baboon, even when the latter beholds him for the first time. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-24. 5927-5929). When a baboon sees a person it calls his or her name even if has never seen the person before. It tells the name to the others as the person passes by.

Baboons plan to attack ||xabbiten ||xabbiten. ||xabbiten ||xabbiten asks them what they are saying and then makes remarks about their ugly appearance and climbs a Krieboom tree. He deceives the baboons by calling out to white farmers as if they were near, because baboons fear white men and their guns.
Means of defending a dog from baboons

A means of defending a dog from a Baboon, by telling him that it belongs to a young woman. (L V.-24. 5948-5956). The people deceive the baboons and the baboons act as if they were not intending to kill the dog, but merely wanted to play with it.
Baboon's ss'o |a and hair used as charms against illness

...further described the value attached, by the Bushmen, to Sso/oa found in the possession of Baboons; also its great use to the latter. The hair of the Baboon considered as a charm (L V.-24. 5957-5967). Baboons keep Ssho |oa (ss'o |a) in their cheek, which people take out and keep when they kill them. They believe that this stick of Ssho |oa prevents the baboon from feeling pain and illness. Baboons live long and don't know illness, but if they do get ill it is severe and kills them.
Chippings made by Dia!kwain's father (before the time of the 'Boers')

Chippings of Gemsbok, Quagga, Ostriches, etc., executed by Xaa-ttin (father of the informant), to be found at the place (not yet identified) called !kann, where these animals used formerly to come to drink. In English, after Dia!kwain (L V.-24. 5963 rev., note). About the chippings made by Dia!kwain's father Xaa-ttin before the Dutch ('Boers') came. The chippings depict various game animals near to where the animals used to drink.

In former times, when animals were people, the Baboons were jealous of a young Quagga woman, who lived with them, on account of the notice attracted by her great size. For this reason, as well as for her fatness, they killed her, telling the other people that her flesh was that of a young gemsbok. In Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain, who had it from his father Xaattin (L V.-25. 5993-5997). The Punishment of the Baboon, which appears to be a continuation of the above fable, was narrated to Dia!kwain by an older female relation named Ttuobboken !kaugn (L V.-24. 5974-5991). An explanatory note to the story of the Punishment of the Baboon was also given by Dia!kwain from information received from his mother, =kamme-an (L V.-24. 5992). An account of when Baboons were people and ate human flesh, and were cursed as a result: the Baboon cooks 'gemsbok's' flesh on the hunting-ground and takes it home to feed the people, but deceives them because it is actually the flesh of a human being. The people are suspicious and question a child who was there on the hunting-ground with the Baboon. The child tells them that they are actually eating human flesh. The people plot to punish the Baboon and make him sit on hot stones so that he burns his buttocks. Baboons' tails are still hard and carry the burn marks to this day, because the people cursed the Baboon to eat only certain plants and bitter-tasting food and retain this appearance.
The woman eaten by Baboons: a fragment of the account

In former times, when animals were people, the Baboons were jealous of a young Quagga woman, who lived with them, on account of the notice attracted by her great size. For this reason, as well as for her fatness, they killed her, telling the other people that her flesh was that of a young gemsbok. In Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain, who had it from his father Xaattin (L V.-25. 5993-5997). The Punishment of the Baboon, which appears to be a continuation of the above fable, was narrated to Dia!kwain by an older female relation named Ttuobboken !kaugn (L V.-24. 5974-5991). An explanatory note to the story of the Punishment of the Baboon was also given by Dia!kwain from information received from his mother, =kamme-an (L V.-24. 5992). A story of the Early Race (or 'First Time') when all things were people. The Baboons eat a woman who lives with them because she is fat.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V-25 or BC151_A2_1_074
The woman who was killed by the Baboons

In former times, when animals were people, the Baboons were jealous of a young Quagga woman, who lived with them, on account of the notice attracted by her great size. For this reason, as well as for her fatness, they killed her, telling the other people that her flesh was that of a young gemsbok. In Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain, who had it from his father Xaa-ttin (L V.-25. 5993-5997). The Punishment of the Baboon, which appears to be a continuation of the above fable, was narrated to Dia!kwain by an older female relation named Ttuobboken !kaugn (L V.-24. 5974-5991). An explanatory note to the story of the Punishment of the Baboon was also given by Dia!kwain from information received from his mother, =kamme-an (L V.-24. 5992). When the Quagga was a person she resembled a boulder and the Baboons feared her size and killed her.

The Baboons are also said to assemble together and play at the =gebbi-ggu, at night, like the Bushmen, singing like the Bushman women, and imitating the songs which they have heard the people sing. (L V.-25. 5998-6005). =gebbi-ggu

A curious description of a dance and other doings of sorcerers was given in explanation of No. 3 of Mr Stows copies of Bushman paintings (L V.-22. 5755-5775). Further details regarding sorcerers (suggested by Mr J.M. Orpens copy of Bushman paintings - published in the for July, 1874) were also given by Dia!kwain (L V.-25. 6008-6013).
=gebbi-ggu Jan Plat's aunt Natta sang the

=gebbi-ggu Jan Plat's aunt Natta sang and taught the people the singing of the . She could imitate (by singing) a ewe's call to its young as well as the call of a partridge, using different parts of her throat.

The !koroken-!koroken (Telophonus . . .) must not be mocked by the Bushman children. The result of so doing described. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-25. 6014-6024). The !koroken-!koroken is said also to know what is passing at a distance, and to come and tell things to the Bushmen. Partly in English after and partly in Bushman (L V.-25. 6021 rev. and 6022 rev.). It comes and tells people the bad things it knows about. It tries to make people understand what it is telling by coming to them again. According to Dia!kwain there are many stories about it.

The tip of the tongue of the Springbok is not eaten by children. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-25. 6025-6030). When the springbok's tongue-tip is eaten, the person stumbles over a stone and stubs his or her toe.

A description of the preparation of Meal, from the !kauru ( . . . . . ) berries, was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain. This is said to have been done formerly by the Quagga, in the days when she was a woman, and carried a sieve (L V.-25. 5997 rev.-6001 rev., note). In Early Times the Quagga and the Baboon were people. The Quagga possessed a mat or a sieve that she used when making flour or meal out of roasted and ground-up berries.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VII-1 or BC151_A2_1_075
Fragment of a story about the old man, the little Hare and the travelling Lions

The Old Man, the Little Hare, and the Lions. Related by =giri-sse (L VII.-1. 6032-6040, partly translated). A fragment of the above story was also related by =giri-sse (L VII.-1. 6031). Explanatory note in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L VII.-1. 6031 rev. and 6032 rev.). kumm
The old man's song (written again separately, from =girri-sse's dictation)

The Old Man, the Little Hare, and the Lions. Related by =giri-sse (L VII.-1. 6032-6040, partly translated). A fragment of the above story was also related by =giri-sse (L VII.-1. 6031). Explanatory note in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L VII.-1. 6031 rev. and 6032 rev.). kumm
Words and Sentences. Given by =girri-sse (L VII.-1. 6041-6044). Includes the sentence 'I come from the strong water', meaning the Breakwater Convict Station.
A fragment of the story of the early morning
One person not to stand over another in the early morning. By =girri-sse (L VII.-1. 6045 and 6046). A fragment of the account of what happens when one stands in the early morning.
Personal history of Hendrick Beren and some words
About Hendrik Beren, an employee of Mr Willmott, and some words given by him.
From 'Jan Plat' at Charlton House, Mowbray

Words and Sentences. Given by 'Jan Plat' (L VII.-1. 6046a-6046c). Some words and sentences given by Jan Plat at Charlton House in Mowbray. The contribution includes some personal details, such the names of some of his relations. On p.6046c Lloyd notes that Jan Plat and Dia!kwain left Calvinia together.
Personal history of Jan Plat (he leaves Calvinia with Dia!kwain)

An account of Jan Plat's movements with his travelling companion, Dia!kwain, and his meeting with his wife, who was keeping sheep in Louriet. A further account of Jan Plat's travels with Dia!kwain and the farmer Louw, whose sheep Dia!kwain had been keeping. Jan Plat states that Dia!kwain went with Louw to Kenhardt and then to the Free State.
Amsterdam Battery, near Cape Town: July 15/79
Name, etc., of a Bushman at the Amsterdam Battery, in 1879 (L VII.-1. 6046g). Words. Given by Xu gwai (L VII.-1. 6046g-6046j). Also known as Jantje George.

Name and other information regarding 'Friedrich Hortnoop', a relative of Dia!kwains (L VII.-1. 6046f, 60461, 6046k rev.). Some personal information given about Jan Plat's travelling companion, a |xam called Friedrich Hortnoop (or Frederick Hottentot) including the date and place of his trial and a brief physical description. His prisoner number was 7061. Friedrich Hortnoop left Mowbray in the company of Jan Plat on 10 January 1884 to return to Bushmanland. His grandfather was Dia!kwain's father's brother.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-1 or BC151_A2_1_076

Names of Animals (L VIII.-1. 6047-6049, 21. 7828-7830, 7834, 7836-7838, 7841, 23. 8068 rev., 8070 rev., 25. 8260 rev., 32. 8811rev., 8875 rev.). Some names of animals and other things from daily life given by |han=kass'o.
Genealogical information concerning the family of |han=kass'o (or Klein Jantje)
Information regarding narrators family. In English after and in Bushman by /han=kass'o (L VIII.-1. 6052 and 6053, 19. 7671, 26. 8302 rev.).
Remarks concerning copies of Bushman pictures nos. I-XXIV Collected By Mr H.C. Schunke, and deposited in the Grey Library

Explanatory remarks concerning copies of Bushmen Paintings and Etchings, collected by Mr. H.C. Schunke and deposited in the Grey Library. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after |han=kass'o (L VIII.-1. 6054-6057, 6061-6073). A list of remarks by |han=kass'o alongside the numbers (I-XXIV) of a collection of copies of paintings found in the Grey Library. These paintings are mostly of animals and rainmakers and their work with the rain.
Cattle drink at the water and eat grass, and then sleep when they are full.
!khoa ka ||kerri-ssi !kau An account of the rain's things or
!khoa ka ||kerri-ssi !kau The rain's 'things' (or ) of |han=kass'o's country have large bodies and dwell in water; some of them kill people when they bite them.
The personal histories of various people

Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them.-Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after lhan=kasso. (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., Note, 11. 6969 rev., Note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.) Biographical information about some |xam individuals and their relations.
!au The or shaped rib-bone used by Bushmen in eating some kinds of food
The !au, or shaped rib-bone, used by Bushmen in eating certain food. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6082). The facing page contains a note as to how it is shaped or 'worked'.

The /khu, or Bushman soup spoon. This is a brush of native manufacture, the stem of which is also used to scratch the fire together. By |han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6083 and 6084). The |khu is made by the men who bind together the back hairs of the |gipp (Proteles, or aardwolf). There are also details about the springbok's 'paxwax', or |kuerri, in this account of the making of the soup spoon.
!kabbi The : a bird which has white legs and is eaten
!kabbi, About the or partridge, named by |han-kass'o after seeing one in a picture.
|ka kau The : a little bird said by the Bushmen, by whom it is not eaten, to laugh at the wildcat
ka kau About the | bird, which laughs at the wild cat and is not eaten by people.

Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. (L VIII.-26. 8293-8302, 8315-8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.-10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.-1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.-31. 8770-8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen is making Arrows. Preparation thereof. (L VIII.-1. 6088-6091). The marking of Arrows. (L VIII.-26. 8289-8392). Arrow Bags. (L VIII. 30. 8663 rev., note). About the making of arrow-heads: the head is made from a white stone and fixed into the end of a reed; they are used for shooting springbok.
kwae The adhesive substance (|) used in arrowmaking and its preparation for use

Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-26. 8293-8302, 8315-8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.-10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.-1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.-31. 8770-8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen is making Arrows. kauru-opua The ||, or little water-hole found in rock or stone
kauru-opua, The || or a small water-hole, is found in flat stones on the ground.
Rainmaking, when the wind is in the north
Rain-making. By |han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6093-6095). The work of the rainmakers; how they 'grasp' the rain's 'ribs'. Also about the rain and the north wind.
Wind and Weather. The Four Winds. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6096-6101). The north wind blows underneath the rain-clouds and makes them strong.
Wind and Weather. The Four Winds. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6096-6101). The west wind turns back the rain-clouds and sends them to the east.
Wind and Weather. The Four Winds. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6096-6101). The south wind blows, 'standing above', and 'makes dust'.
Wind and Weather. The Four Winds. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6096-6101). The east wind is cold and blows strongly. The people have to make shelters and light fires to warm themselves when it comes.
Drought. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6102-6106). When the west wind turns back the rain-clouds there is a drought or 'want' of rain and the people are thirsty and have to travel far to fetch water.
Food of the Bushmen, found in their country
Certain kinds of Food, used by Bushmen. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6107, 18. 7598-7601).
!goin-!goin The use of the , followed by an account of a Bushman dance

The employment of the !goin-!goin (the !goin-!goin consists of a [variously-sized] blade of wood, attached by a little cord to a short stick. The latter is held in the hand of the performer, and the blade of wood (attached to the string) is then, by means of the stick-handle, whirled about in the air, producing a strong whirring sound. When several of these instruments are used at a time, a considerable effect must be produced), followed by the account of a Bushman dance, in which the men dance, one woman beats the drum, and the rest of the women sit, clapping their hands for the dancers. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6108-6127). !goin-!goin
The preparation of the drum; ears of springbok are tied to the feet of the men who dance

The Bushman drum, and dancing-rattles. Mode of preparation of the latter, by the women. By /han=kasso, (L VIII.-1. 6127-6137). The drum is prepared by pulling springbok skin over a pot's mouth. The men tie springbok's ears on their feet (the insteps) as dancing rattles to make sounds while they dance.
The preparation of the springbok's ears

The Bushman drum, and dancing-rattles. Mode of preparation of the latter, by the women. By /han=kasso, (L VIII.-1. 6127-6137). The springbok's ear dancing rattles are made from dried springbok's ear skin with berries sewn inside.
How the prepared springbok's ears are tied on

The Bushman drum, and dancing-rattles. Mode of preparation of the latter, by the women. By /han=kasso, (L VIII.-1. 6127-6137). see A description of how the springbok ears are tied to the top of the male dancer's feet after being prepared and filled (with berries).
The names of |kaggen's wife, son and daughter
The names of the wife, son, and daughter of the Mantis. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6137 rev.).
The loss of ||kabbo's tobacco bag, which was stolen by a hungry dog, belonging to !gou !nui, named 'Blom'
An account of how ||kabbo's tobacco pouch was stolen by a dog ('Blom') while he slept at night, and of the subsequent search for it.
||kabbo's song on the loss of his tobacco pouch
||kabbo's song sung on the occasion of the theft of his tobacco pouch by the dog 'Blom'. It concerns his 'tobacco-hunger'.
kwa kwara The , or korhaan malkop
kwa kwara The song of the , or korhaan malkop

Words and sentences given by |han=kass'o at the South African Museum
Names of Animals, mainly identified at the South African Museum. Given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-2. 6141-6145, 9. 6770-6775, 21. 7817, 7819-7821, 7842 and 7843, 7843, 7846, 31. 8790 rev. and 8791).
Crows and a note on secretary birds

Another version of the story of the Crow Messengers appears, here, in connexion with the adventure related above ; /kwammana and his companion being, in this instance, those who were found by the successful bird (Corvus scapulatus). (L VIII.-2. 6147-6157).
The Mantis and |kwammana visit the Dassie's house

The Mantis and |kwammana go out visiting together. The Mantis involves himself in a quarrel with a young Dasse (Hyrax), and stones fall upon him and |kwammana. The latter, upon whom they lie loosely, is first rescued; while the Mantis owes his rescue to the entreaties of his wife, who prevails upon the people to take him out.-His teasing and troublesome ways are much blamed. (L VIII.-2. 6165-6193, and 6195.) Another version of the story of the Crow Messengers appears, here, in connexion with the adventure related above; |kwammana and his companion being, in this instance, those who were found by the successful bird (Corvus scapulatus). (L VIII.-2. 6147-6157) By the same narrator was also given the Rescue of |kwammana and the Mantis, and their return home. The Blue Crane, who is the elder sister of |kaggen, pities his sad condition.-Specimens of the peculiar manner in which the Bushman language is spoken by the wife of |kaggen, and by the Ichneumon, respectively, are here given. (L VIII.-2. 6196-6231, 3. 6232-6236.) A note regarding the =kam-!kwe, a member of the party which went to the rescue of /kwammana and his companion (L VII.-2. 6195 rev. and 6196 rev.). |kwammana and |kaggen (the Mantis) both drink from ostrich egg-shells offered to them, |kwammana by the young bee and |kaggen by the Dassie who passes water into his shell. |kaggen curses the Dassie when he tastes its urine and the mother Dassie makes rocks roll on |kaggen and |kwammana. The people take |kaggen out from under the rocks only because his wife has asked them to.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-3 or BC151_A2_1_078

The Mantis visits the abode of the Ticks, attempts to take some of their food, and is well beaten by them. He flies away, goes into the water, and returns home where he is pitied and lectured by the Ichneumon. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-3. 6236-6258, 6267-6269). Also (L VIII.-20. 7790-7811; L VIII.-20. 7812-7816, 22. 7906-7956).
The !khau lizard and the rainclouds - springbok hunting follows rain; and the song of the !khau lizard

The !khau (a lizard of the genus Agama), which interferes with the coming of the rain-clouds. Springbok hunting follows the rain. (L VIII.-3. 6232 rev.-6234 rev., 6259-6266, 6269-6271). !khau, kochelman !khau
The |kain |kain, the girls and the Mantis

The |kain |kain bird stabs a girl in the breast when she lies ill. The |kain |kain rubs her blood on his nose and goes to another girl. The |kain |kains come to the house of |kaggen (the Mantis) and |kaggen tells the girl's mother to give her a knife to take to bed with her. The girl stabs the bird when it comes, and the other birds scatter and run away. The people remark that |kaggen warned them about the |kain |kain, even though he usually lies and teases.
The !kwai !kwai, the Mantis and the children

The !kwai-!kwai, the Mantis, and the Children. The !kwai-!kwai, who was formerly a man, and is now a bird (in appearance somewhat resembling a 'duiker'), comes, during the absence of their parents, to kill the children. They are defended by the Mantis, who causes the death of !kwai-!kwai. By /han#kasso (L VIII.-3. 6304-6322, 4. 6323-6333). A note to the above story was also given by /han#kasso (L VIII.-18. 7596, 7597 and 7595 rev.). !kwai !kwai

Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han#kasso (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.). A note on the personal history of |han=kass'o and names of his relations as well as an explanation of one of the names: Stone-Earbone.
The story of !gwa !nuntu and the Elephants
The !gwa-!nuntu, whose grandchild is carried off by Elephants, and recovered by himself. By /han#kasso (L VIII.-4. 6334-6413, 5. 6414-6455 !xwe ||na ssho !kui
When Bushmen were springbucks and cried

...It was also stated by him that the Bushmen were formerly Springbok, and were changed into Bushmen by the Mantis (L VIII.-4. 6365 rev.). In the Early Times, when people were springboks, they cried like children when |kaggen (the Mantis) shot them. |kaggen said they should become people because of how they cried.
The approach of strangers makes Bushmen sleepy
The approach of strangers causes us to become drowsy. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-4. 6379 rev. and 6380 rev.).
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-5 or BC151_A2_1_080
The She-Rhinoceros and her elder daughter's suitors

The Rhinoceros and her daughters suitors. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-5. 6456-6504). The She-Rhinoceros has two daughters. The youngest is Driving Away (Ssuai-ssuai-||a-|uhan), who asks her mother for food as a reward for telling her (by means of a song) when people come to court her elder daughter (!kwa !khe). The She-Rhinoceros chases them away with her short horn, and the !gwiten (Silver Fox) throws a stick at them as they run away, complaining about the dust that has been kicked up. The Leopard goes to !kwa-!khe and the younger sister starts her singing again. The elder sister asks her to stop, but Driving Away still wants the reward of food from the She-Rhinoceros and sings about the new suitor. The mother instructs her to fetch the long horn, because it is the Leopard and he will not be afraid of her. !kwa-!khe beats her mother on the back with a stick and leaves with the Leopard. The cowardly suitors (the Jackals and Hyena) see the Leopard bringing !kwa-!khe as his wife and discuss how they would have married her had her mother not fought them.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-6 or BC151_A2_1_081

The Mantis (/kaggen) makes and brings up a young eland. /kwammana, who is informed of its existence by the Ichneumon, kills it, to the grief of /kaggen. The latter, having pierced the gall of the dead eland, takes an ostrich feather to wipe it from his eyes, which feather he then throws up into the sky, ordering it to become the Moon. A description of porcupine hunting, in which the moonlight is of service, follows. This story, which /han=kasso had from his mother, /Xabbi-an, throws light upon one or two points which had remained somewhat obscure in the versions earlier collected (L VIII.-6. 6506-6595 1/2). |kaggen (the Mantis) takes one of |kwammana's shoes and soaks it in the water. It grows into an eland and |kaggen returns to look at it again and again. The Ichneumon sees the eland while he is pretending to sleep and tells his father (|kwammana) about the eland. While |kaggen is away, |kwammana kills the eland. |kaggen is angry with the people for killing the eland without telling him, as he is the one who made it. He pierces a gall, which breaks and covers him so that he can no longer see. He finds a feather, which he picks up and throws into the sky and which becomes the Moon.
A description of porcupine hunting, in which the moonlight is of service, follows (L VIII.-6. 6506-6595 1/2).
When the lion is coming, he is preceded by an apparition which resembles a real lion. By /han=kasso (L. VIII.-6. 6576 rev.).

Different customs concerning the eating of the Porcupine. By /han=kasso (L VII.-6. 6590 rev.-6594 rev.). The people who live where the sun sets (the place where Dia!kwain and his people come from) roast and eat the porcupine on the hunting-ground, but |han=kass'o's people take the porcupine home when there are no springbok.

!kuerre-!kuerre About the bird and what people say when it flutters its wings.
Words and sentences given by |han=kass'o: parts of the body

Words and Sentences given by |han=kass'o naming parts of the body. Parts of the body. By Man-tonno (L XXII. 10407-10413). Ditto.By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6059 and 6051, 7. 6598 rev.). Names for certain bones, etc. (L VIII.-16. 7401 and 7402).
About the locust as well as the bird that eats it.

The Mantis and his son-in-law /kwammana are both to be seen in the rainbow, the Mantis uppermost and /kwammana underneath. (L VIII.-7. 6600 rev. & 6601 rev.). |kaggen (the Mantis) and |kwammana can be seen in the rainbow and are the same colour as the part they live in. The people call the rainbow by |kwammana's name.
Words and sentences given by |han=kass'o: names of colours and patterns
Names for Colours, etc. Given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-7. 6601, 6606 and 6605 rev., 24. 8170).
When it seems as if the rain will break, the people start seeking springbok. An account of the driving and shooting of springbok, and hunting methods in general.
The !gwe plant, from which poison is derived. (L VIII.-7. 6603 rev.).
kui sse A girl takes | hair and throws it into the sky, where it becomes locusts, which jump away.
When a swarm of locusts comes flying past the people must go to the place where the locusts settle and make fire. The rainmaker, |kannu, grew locusts and gave them to the people.
||kunnu who possessed locusts and rain, and was entreated for rain by a relative of the narrator. (L VIII.-7. 6639 rev. -6646 rev.).
The hail is the rain's legs
The hail considered to be the legs of the rain. (L VIII.-7. 6652 rev., note). Also, some words pertaining to rain and related weather conditions.
kerri The || bird drives locusts into bushes while the sun is shining, which they do not normally do.
The ill effects of eating !kui ( . . . . ) were mentioned by /han=kasso (L VIII.7. 6679 rev., note). gambro, kui
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-8 or BC151_A2_1_083

The Son of the Wind. By |han=kasso (L VIII.-8. 6687-6708). |na ka ti's mother tells him not to say the name of the son of the Wind until his father has made a hut for them. When the father is finished, |na ka ti calls the Wind's name and then runs to the hut. The Wind blows away the people's houses, except for the Wind's hut. The Wind's mother picks up the son of the Wind and it stops blowing. A strong shelter must be made before calling the Wind's name.
The Wind was formerly a man, but is now a bird, and lives in the mountain. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-8. 6709-6713, and 6694 rev., note).
The Wind Notes to the story of

The Wind thought to be seen, in the form of a bird, by the brother-in-law of the narrator when a child. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-8. 6713-6724). ||goo-ka-!kui (Smoke's man, or Witbooi Tooren) told |han=kass'o that he had seen the Wind at the mountains at Haarfontein (or =ko a xa) and had thrown a stone at it, thinking it to be a bird. As a result the Wind blew hard and took up dust.

Wind-making; followed by a long discourse upon springbok hunting. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-8. 6725-6769 rev.). The people beat the bushes with a stick and call to the north wind to help them travel quickly in front of the game. The hunters do not wish to shoot while the springbok are running, as they are too numerous. Some hunters drive, some run and some wait in a screen to shoot the springbok. Bewitched springbok do not fall even when shot, and must be left alone.
kuarri A note on how || is eaten by porcupines, but is poisonous to people.
A note on the locust and its names, proper and |xam, as well as its appearance.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-9 or BC151_A2_1_084
Words and sentences given by |han=kass'o at the South African Museum

Names of Animals, mainly identified at the South African Museum. Given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-2. 6141-6145, 9. 6770-6775, 21. 7817, 7819-7821, 7842 and 7843, 7843, 7846, 31. 8790 rev. and 8791). A list list of |xam names of animals given by |han=kass'o at the South African Museum as well as some details about them.

A game played with the Phyllomorpha paradoxa or 'Withered Leaf' Insect. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-9. 6775-6785). The withered-leaf insect distracts crying children and the people protect it from burning in the fire and laugh at its head-nodding movements.

=Nuturu dances for the children and sings to herself until the people return. She takes off her 'face's horns' and the people see that her face underneath is white and beautiful. The hunters give her the fatty springbok breasts to eat and their own wives get lean meat.
!haken, a food resembling 'Bushman rice' is also used by Bushmen. (L VIII.-9. 6789 rev., note).

Different kinds of rain. The children to hide from rain that is likely to be strong, for fear of the lightning. (L VIII.-9. 6813 rev.-6815 rev.). Liquid rain falls gently, a big rain falls in hard streams, another rain 'makes lightening' and makes the place black.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-10 or BC151_A2_1_085
kerri The ||: a bird which eats locusts; and locust-hunting

kerri The || bird eats locusts and is thus called the locust-bird. They drive the locusts into the bushes, where the people collect them and roast them in a fire. The people thirst after collecting locusts and need water. The rain then breaks and the people go and hunt for springbok.
!huin The new maiden who threw into the sky; which became stars, and the wood ashes which were upon it, the Milky Way

A Girl being angry with her mother, because the latter asked her for a certain kind of food which she had put to roast in the fire, threw it with the wood-ashes that were upon it, into the air. The food was changed into stars, and the ashes became the Milky Way. By |han=kasso (L VIII.-10. 6879-6884). !huin

The Mantis and Koro-tuiten. The Mantis learns from Koro-tuiten how to obtain 'Bushman-rice' (i.e. larvae of the ants) with ease; but, acting ungratefully towards his instructor, he soon loses his newly acquired power. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-10. 6885-6939). A note states that Koro-tuiten was formerly a man of the early race (L VIII.-10. 6885 rev.). 'Bushman rice' may be dug by both men and women. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-10. 6888 rev., note). |kaggen (the Mantis) is out hunting when he comes across Koro-tuiten, who flies down into a 'Bushman-rice' hole and carries out a kaross full of 'Bushman-rice' (ant larvae). |kaggen asks Koro-tuiten to anoint him with its perspiration so he too can get lots of 'Bushman-rice'. |kaggen breaks all his things (including his digging-stick), but gets a kaross full of 'Bushman rice'. He returns home and goes out to meet Koro-tuiten again, and fills many karosses of 'Bushman-rice'. Koro-tuiten asks him to divide his 'Bushman-rice', but |kaggen refuses. The next day when he tries to dive into the earth he crushes his brow, because the earth is now hard.
|kuamman-a, accompanied by the Mantis and the young Ichneumon, visits the house of the |ku, or, The Mantis and the Proteles

... the account of a visit paid by /kwammana, with a young Ichneumon and the Mantis, to the abode of the 'Loffelhund' (Proteles); where the Mantis again gets into trouble. (L VIII.1-6939-6944, 11. 6945-6977). |kwammana and the Ichneumon visit the Proteles (|ku) and |kaggen (the Mantis) insists on coming with them. |kwammana begs the mother Proteles for a little Proteles to eat and she gives him a lean one. They return home with meat for the women, but |kaggen turns back and returns to the Proteles's house where he calls for the mother Proteles to give him another of her children. She knocks him into the fire he has built and he returns home, where |kwammana and the Ichneumon scold him for his foolish actions.

Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-26. 8293-8302, 8315-8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.-10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.-1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.-31. 8770-8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen in making Arrows. Preparation thereof. (L VIII.-1. 6088-6091). The marking of Arrows. (L VIII.-26. 8289-8392). Arrow Bags. (L VIII. 30. 8663 rev., note). The names and uses of poisons and the feathering of arrows.
Bushman rice' may be dug by both men and women. (L VIII.-10. 6888 rev., note). gambro None
A young ram springbok grows horns on his forehead when he becomes a grown-up springbok.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-11 or BC151_A2_1_086
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-12 or BC151_A2_1_087
!gaunu-tsaxau (the son of the Mantis), the Baboons, and the Mantis

The son of the Mantis is killed by the Baboons, and restored to life by his father. This piece contains specimens of the manner in which the Bushman language is supposed to be spoken by baboons. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-11. 6978-7014, 12. 7065-7094). !gaunu-tsaxau, the son of |kaggen (the Mantis) collects sticks for his father to shoot at the Baboons and comes across some Baboons, who beat him and break his head. |kaggen dreams that the Baboons have killed !gaunu-tsaxau and are playing with his eye. He awakes and goes to join in the Baboons' game and the child's eye smells its father's scent and plays about so that the Baboons cannot catch it. |kaggen catches his child's eye and anoints it with his perspiration and it flies into the air and into the quiver's bag. He flies into the water and speaks to his child's eye, wanting his child to return to life again. It grows back into his son and |kaggen catches him and takes him back home.

/ku-te-!gaua, who could enter fire unharmed, enables the Mantis to do the same. The ingratitude of the latter to his instructor again brings him into trouble; and his newly acquired power deserts him. (L VIII.-11. 7015-7031, 12. 7032-7064). |ku-te !gaua goes through fire and draws out cats, 'such cat's as had no equal in beauty' and then skins them. |kaggen (the Mantis) sings like |ku-te !gaua and also gets skins, but he refuses to share them with |ku-te !gaua. |ku-te !gaua angrily says that |kaggen and the skins will burn in the fire, which happens.
Various foods and the protection of the rain for a fungus

!haken, a food resembling 'Bushman rice' is also used by Bushmen. (L VIII.-9. 6789 rev., note). That !haken above which a certain fungus grows is given to the old people. (L VIII.-11. 6945 rev.-6954 rev.). !gu !gu !haken !haken

Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.). Personal information about a man called ||gabbe-Tka, or Piet Titus.
Personal information about a man called kkuirri-ttu (|han=kass'o's uncle) who was killed by a white man over some missing oxen.
Words and sentences: names of animals

The mode of preparation of the !nabbe ( . . . . ), made from the tail hair of various animals. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-11. 7005 rev.-7007 rev.). The tail and tail-hair of various jackals and foxes are compared and used in the making of the brush.
kitten-|kitten A bird found in Bushmanland called the |.

A man, who has missed his aim in shooting, throws springbok bones, in order that another man may do likewise. (L VIII.-11. 7010 rev., note). !hau-!hau is a charm made so that a man may make another miss his aim on the hunting-ground.
The man who ordered his wife to cut off his ears

The man (belonging to the early race) who ordered his wife to cut off his ears. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-12. 7095-7097). A man thinks his younger brother's head-skin has been cut off, but he has in fact only had his hair shaved off.
How the !gabbaken-!gabbaken (the Mason Wasp) punished his wife for making personal remarks

The Mason Wasp (? Genus Lyrops) who shot his wife for making a personal remark. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-12. 7098-7103). The Mason Wasp shoots his wife with an arrow intended for the Hare, then cries regretfully when he sees that she is dead.
The lynx; its flesh eaten by Bushmen, but not by the Bushman women; the manner of hunting it, etc.
The flesh of the Lynx not eaten by Bushman women. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-12. 7103-7113).
The !kau who brought home his own flesh as food

A tale of the Early Race about the !khau lizard, who brings home his own flesh as food so that his wife will think he has brought home a Quagga. Eventually the wife tells their child to go out with his father and see what flesh he is bringing and the child sees his father go into a whirlwind and come out rolling his flesh in a net. The woman throws away the husband's flesh and leaves him for her father's people.
Fat; division of into small quantities.(L VIII-12. 7108 rev.-7110 rev., note).
!ka-ka |khueten A note about a certain spider called the .
Huts made by the Bushman women. The shelter for them made by the men. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-12. 7111 rev. and 7112 rev., note).
Regarding the children of the Mantis
The three children of the Mantis. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-12. 7074 rev.-7076 rev., note).
The Mantis giver of names to places
The Mantis is further said, by the Bushmen, to have given places their names. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-12. 7033 rev. and 7034 rev., note).
Words and sentences: various expressions for being angry
Various expressions for being angry or comfortable with another person.
What people say when talking about the flight of bees.
How various mice make their nests
How various kinds of mice make their nests in Bushmanland.
Words and sentences: terms for various relationships by marriage
Terms for various relationships by marriage. (L VIII.-12. 7067 rev. and 7068 rev., 32. 8794 rev.).
The hunting of hare, and its habits.
