Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-13 or BC151_A2_1_088
A note regarding the latter stars [named by !gaunu] was given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-13. 7119 rev.). About a rain called 'Aquilae's water' and about rain-clouds which resemble celestial bodies.
!khau The song of the lizard's child, which it sings while following its father home after he has cut off his own flesh.

!koa A song of the Early Race in which the (or Muishond) cuts off his own flesh with his knife and cooks and eats it, until his body grows small from all the cutting. He asks the west wind what to do.
The names of some Bushmen. (L VIII.-13. 7195 rev.). Names of some of |han=kass'o's relations.
Names for certain Winds. (L VIII.-13. 7196 rev. ).
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-14 or BC151_A2_1_089
Agama The death of the !kau (a lizard of the genus )

A story of the !khau (the Kochelman, or Agama lizard) in the Early Times when animals were people (7206opp). As he passes through the mountains, they squeeze and break him. The front of his body falls off and becomes !guru |na and his back falls of and becomes |xe-!khwai.
The death of the !kau Remarks by |han=kass'o on the preceding story ()

The death of the !kau |han=kass'o's mother sends him to collect water and kills the leveret (hare) while he is away. |han=kass'o' is upset and his mother tells him a story () to soothe him. She tells him not to play with meat (animals that will be eaten).

The part of Bushmanland formerly occupied by //kabbo. Given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-14. 7215-7217). A place called '||gubo' by the |xam is called 'Blaauwpits' by the 'Bastaards' because the rocks there are black slate. ||gubo is also ||kabbo's (Jantje Tooren's) place.

||xuobbeten is carried away by the lion while she sleeps. It bites her head and kills her. It puts her in its mouth and carries her down to the water. The people name the water '||xuobbeten' because it has no bushes.

A story about the wind and the rain and the hunting of springbok. People who live facing the rain get their weapons wet, causing bowstrings to break. When the children shoot windward at the herd of springbok, they quickly turn and run leeward. The speaker intends to go and wait at the springbok's water-course or footpaths where they will turn and run along. The springbok must be driven by the women in the evening because they go leeward and behave better when it is cool.

Names of Trees and Plants, and other information regarding them, given partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han=kasso (L VIII.-14. 7219 rev. and 7220 rev., note, 18. 7552 rev.-7754 rev., 21. 7830-7833, 7835, 7847, 23. 8061 rev., 8062 rev. and 8063 rev.,8073 rev., 29. 8601 rev., 8606 rev., 8613 rev., 30. 8637 rev., 31. 8728 rev., 8790, 8791, 8789 rev.). The !kwana thorn tree (and bush) scratches and wounds people who do not wear trousers when they hunt porcupine in the bushes at night.
The springbok resemble the water of the sea
The springbok resemble the water of the sea. There are so many of them the Dutch ('Boers') soon exhaust their ammunition shooting them.
The intelligence and timidity of the jackal
The people laugh at the jackal because it is intelligent and timid.
The mother springbok makes sounds to her kid as she travels and the young springbok responds: the mothers grunt and the kids bleat.
Doings of the springbok and springbok hunting
The behaviour of male and female springbok and various hunting strategies.

|han=kass'o's explanation of the term !nanna-sse: people put bones in a heap in a number of places. Different people take their finished bones and put them in the same place. Much is doneopposite the house of the man who shot the springbok. These practices ensure that the man who shoots springbok will not miss on the hunting-ground when next he hunts.
The women must not eat meat from the shoulder blades of the springbok, or the arrows will miss the game. This is called 'when we shoot our death'.

The springbok possess magic or invisible arrows which make people ill. Little children are not allowed to play on the springbok's skin, because the springbok gets under the people's flesh and makes them ill.
A description of the springboks' bones and the |xam names given to them.

The Bushmen anoint their heads with //hara (which is black and sparkling), mixed with fat, and rub their bodies with tto. (L VIII.-14. 7272 rev.,-7276 rev., note). Tto or 'Roode Klip' is dug out from the mountain side. Precautions to be taken against sorcerers upon these occasions. (L VIII.-14. 7275 and 7276, 7279 and 7380). hara tto. ||hara Tto

The Bushmen anoint their heads with //hara. (which is black and sparkling), mixed with fat, and rub their bodies with tto. (L VIII.-14. 7272 rev.,-7276 rev., note). Tto or 'Roode Klip' is dug out from the mountain side. Precautions to be taken against sorcerers upon these occasions. (L VIII.-14. 7275 and 7276, 7279 and 7380). An account of how tto (rooi klip) is obtained. When the people collect tto, they pound it and then anoint themselves with the mixture as protection against the sorcerers at the tto mine.

|han=kass'o's grandfather Tsatsi puts different kinds of bones away in the sticks of the hut to avoid wounding the first finger of his right hand. If the bones are not treated properly and are eaten by the dogs, he will be wounded and will not be able to shoot properly.
|han=kass'o's father-in-law, ||kabbo ('Dream' or Oud Jantje Tooren), throws bones away, and |han-kass'o does the same because he has married into the family.

Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.). For example, p.7277v tells of a man who became paralysed and lost the use of an arm while carrying a springbok.
Unsuccessful springbok hunting after death of companion (means employed to make it more fortunate)

The hunter is unable to kill a springbok if his companion has been killed. His arrows miss the springbok and if an arrow does hit the springbok it runs on as if not wounded. The women shave parts of the hunter's head (over the temples). This ensures that the springbok will come straight up to the hunters so they can shoot it at close range.
Sorcerers shoot with invisible arrows, causing illness

Sorcerers shoot with invisible arrows, causing illness. The sick man. The aid of the old women to be sought. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-14. 7287 and 7288; 15. 7289-7295). The wounded person feels pain and weariness. The old women 'snore' sick people and remove what ails them. Once 'snored' the person will again feel comfortable.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-15 or BC151_A2_1_090
When a good-looking person is ill
The handsome child, who is ill, is not to be sent to fetch water. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-15. 7296-7298). When a 'good-looking' or handsome person is ill he is taken care of because of his appearance.

The sorcerers see a handsome person and cause him to be ill. The dogs cannot sleep for barking at the sorcerers, and the sick man dies, although he has been doctored. (L VIII.-15. 7298-7303). When a good-looking or 'handsome' person falls ill and dies, the !giten (sorcerers) seize that person. Every time he seems to get better they 'shoot' (bewitch) him again, making him ill, and he never recovers. Their arrows kill people even when they are being 'snored'.
Some sorcerers are said to eat the flesh of the dead. (L VIII.-15. 7304-7306). !giten !giten !giten !giten

The story of |kuken-|u |unu (a caterpillar, larva of Aloa) who was formerly a person of the Early Race. |kuken-|u |unu curses a girl and she falls ill. |kuken-|u |unu pretends to die and the girl dies after him and they are buried. The people move to a different watering-hole and |kuken-|u |unu digs up the girl's body and eats her. He follows after the people and repeats this process a number of times, cursing and eating different girls.
harriten The | bird is found in Bushmanland and resembles a crow.
kuken-|u |unu Concerning the |, which is found abundantly, in Bushmanland
The manner of carrying firewood. By|han=kasso (L VIII.-15. 7360 rev. and 7361 rev., note).

A lion sits waiting for the sun to set so he can stalk people. The people lie down to sleep and the lion steals up on them and drags |a!karaken into the grove. The people name the grove '|a!karaken's grove' after |a!karaken who was carried there by the lion.
Oh old woman! At what place did you grow up?

An insert containing an address to an old woman in which she is asked where she grew up as a child and what the place's name is. It asks her who her friends (or companions) were, and what her people's names are.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-16 or BC151_A2_1_091

An account of the hunting of porcupine and the practices that ensure its success (such as the treatment of their bones). The hunter is 'worked on' by the women before he goes to seek porcupine. The porcupine goes about only at night and remains inside its hole when the place is bright.

The people wait for the porcupines to return to their hole and kill them as they return, including the female porcupine who returns last. Different members of the family get given meat from different porcupines and parts of porcupines.
Various parts of the porcupine are given to specific people in the group, for instance the wife of the man who killed the porcupine eats its tail. The hunter and the children eat its shoulder meat.
Words and sentences: names of bones
Names for certain bones, etc. (L VIII.-16. 7401 and 7402). |xam names and descriptions of various bones and tendons (found in animals).
Porcupine's bones are gathered together and placed on an ostrich breastbone and pouredopposite the hut's entrance.

Different customs concerning the eating of the Porcupine. (L VII.-6. 6590 rev.-6594 rev.). Certain persons not allowed to eat the tail of the Porcupine. (L VIII.-16. 7405-7409, 7408 rev. and 7409 rev.). A part of the Porcupine is used to prevent the evil consequences of eating !kui. (L VIII.-16. 7450 rev., note). A story describing the habits of porcupines and the eating of them. The porcupine seeks food away from its hole and returns to a different hole.
A girl does not eat porcupines' tails

Different customs concerning the eating of the Porcupine. (L VII.-6. 6590 rev.-6594 rev.). Certain persons not allowed to eat the tail of the Porcupine (L VIII.-16. 7405-7409, 7408 rev. and 7409 rev.). A part of the Porcupine is used to prevent the evil consequences of eating !kui. (L VIII.-16. 7450 rev., note). Only old people and married women with their own huts can eat the tail safely.
Method of cooking and eating porcupine
A description of the preparation, cooking, eating and distribution of porcupine meat among the people. The men eat from the backbone, because they want the most meat to be given to the children.

The Rain believed to be ridden by sorcerers. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-27. 8399 rev. and 8400 rev., note). When the Rain is angry with anyone, people may be carried off in the whirlwind, and various transformations effected. The young women should propitiate a water pit, by means of 'buchu' and tto. (L VIII.-16. 7418-7428.) The old people say that when the rain is angry it wants to kill people. It takes the man who made it angry, and all his people, and turns them into frogs at the pond. Their karosses and quiver skins become springboks and their sticks become bushes.
The porcupine's hole is stone on the outside and earth on the inside.
When the people go digging for porcupine they pluck off its quills at its hole and place them neatly ('nicely') together so that the wind will not disperse them.
The people fear the rain's animals because they are things the rain has put aside for its meat. They are the cobra, the puffadder, the tortoise and the great water tortoise.
A young woman of the Early Race of people carried off by the Rain, in the shape of a bull

A young woman of the Early Race is carried off by the Rain in the form of a bull. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-16. 7434-7448). The Rain courted a young woman of the Early Race, because of her scent. The young woman climbs onto the Rain's back and he starts to take her away to his home (the water-pit). The young woman rubs buchu on the Rain, which makes him fall asleep and she steals away from the Rain and returns home.

Frogs are not to be killed, lest drought ensue. An exhortation, to the Bushmen, to be careful of food in time of plenty, is followed by a description of the jackals doings with regard to food, etc. (L VIII.-16. 7449-7451, 7448 rev.-7450 rev., and 7452-7456). |kui

An exhortation, to the Bushmen, to be careful of food in time of plenty, is followed by a description of the jackals doings with regard to food, etc. (L VIII.-16. 7449-7451, 7448 rev.-7450 rev., and 7452-7456). When food is plentiful (in times of abundant rainfall) the people say that they must put the food away properly so they will not be like the jackal, which is always going along looking for where it has put its food (its 'plenty').
Children do not eat jackal's hearts

Little children, among the Bushmen, are not allowed to eat the heart of the Jackal, on account of its great timidity. The heart of the Leopard may, on the contrary, be eaten by them. By /han=kasso (L VIII-16. 7457-7459).
Children do not eat jackal's hearts Notes (to )

A description of some barter, containing allusion to the ill effect of eating Jackals hearts (L VIII.-16. 7456 rev.-7458 rev., 7460, note). |han=kass'o's maternal grandfather (Tsatsi) is given a dog by |gappem-ttu and it kills many jackals. Tsatsi gives a kaross to |gappem-ttu for giving him a dog that kills so many jackals.
The Rain, in the form of an eland, shot by one of the Early Race of people; and the disasters which followed

The Rain, in the form of an Eland, shot by one of the early race of people (which preceded the Bushmen in their country). The disasters which follow. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-16. 7461 and 7462, 17. 7463-7472). A man of the Early Race hunts the Rain (which was formerly an eland) as it grazes. The next day the people try to roast the meat, but it vanishes on the fire and the Rain traps them in their hut. They become frogs and hop away.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-17 or BC151_A2_1_092
The girl of the Early Race who killed the children of the Rain

The Girl (of the Early Race) who killed the Children of the Rain, bringing, thereby, severe punishment upon herself and those who lived with her. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-17. 7473-7519). A girl kills and eats a Water child, tidying up before her mother comes home. This happens a number of times, and eventually the Rain becomes angry and makes a whirlwind gather the hut and the girl into the pond, where she becomes a frog.
Words and sentences: names of millipedes
The names and some descriptions of millipedes and millipede-like insects.
The girl of the Early Race who killed the children of the Rain The occasion on which the story was related to |han=kass'o
The girl of the Early Race who killed the children of the Rain' |han=kass'o was told the story ' when, as a child, he complained about being given too little to eat.
The drought which caused |han=kass'o's grandparents to starve

|han=kass'o's maternal grandmother, =kammi, was lean with starvation during the drought in their country, and his grandfather almost died from starvation during the same drought. The children were the ones who ran the steenbok down in the sun until they collapsed from the heat ('the sun is killing' them).
Young man of the Early Race put into a mouse skin and becomes a lion

Children push a youth into the skin of a Fieldmouse and tell him to 'trot away', which he does, becoming a Lion. The children tell the Lion to go and lie down, which he does. The Lion charges the people and runs at his brother's wife, biting her in the head and dragging her into the reeds.
The Mantis, the Mice and the Beetle
The Mantis, the valiant Striped Mouse , the other Mice, and the Beetle . By /han=kasso (L VIII.-17. 7542-7549, 18. 7550).
Grass in Bushmanland that resembles brushes
A note describing different types of grasses found in Bushmanland, as well as various kinds of brushes (used for wiping the face).
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-18 or BC151_A2_1_093
Men who hunted lions with bones

Two brothers succesfully hunt Lions with bones, until the younger brother goes out hunting alone and is killed. The elder brother waits at home for his younger brother and the Lions come and kill him.
A description of two edible plants found near water in Bushmanland.
Men who hunted lions with bones Further details of

(Further details of the story of the men who hunted with bones.) The elder brother waits at home for his younger brother to return from hunting Lions. He sees the Lion's eyes shining and thinks they are stars and they approach and seize him. There follows a discussion of the bones the brothers made into knobkerries in order to hunt Lions.
Some beliefs of the Bushmen with regard to clouds and wind, etc. (L VIII.-18. 7589-7592).
The ||ua (Fox) speaks, saying 'Thou art thinking thou art awake' and makes the Koranna sleep, even though they are supposed to be keeping watch.
The Korannas brought guns (while they felt that they had not a little cattle)
|han=kass'o speaks of the guns brought by the Koranna to his people's place when they acquired cattle. Before then the Koranna had used blades.
Beasts of prey were once people
All things were once people. They became beasts of prey when the Anteater and the Lynx cursed each other.
Sneezing believed to be a sign that the name of the person who sneezes has been uttered. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-18. 7594 rev. and 7595 rev., note).
The !kwai !kwai, the Mantis and the children A note to the story of

The !kwai-!kwai, the Mantis, and the Children. The !kwai-!kwai, who was formerly a man, and is now a bird (in appearance somewhat resembling a 'duiker'), comes, during the absence of their parents, to kill the children. They are defended by the Mantis, who causes the death of !kwai-!kwai. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-3. 6304-6322, 4. 6323-6333). A note to the above story was also given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-18. 7596, 7597 and 7595 rev.). !kwai !kwai !kwai !kwai
Food eaten by Bushmen (five types of berries and roots)
Certain kinds of Food, used by Bushmen. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6107, 18. 7598-7601). An account of the food (plants and berries) eaten by people throughout the year.
The girl, of the Early Race of people, who married a Baboon

A girl is becoming a new maiden and goes to lie down (in her hut). She says the Baboon's name. The Baboon sings to her so that her face will change shape and resemble his own. The girl runs away to the Baboon, who waits on the hill. She marries him.
The !khau carried off by a Lion
The !khau (a Lizard of the Genus Agama) who would not listen to the advice of his wife, and was carried off by a lion. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-18. 7626-7638, 20. 7728-7745). !khau !khau
The Lion can transform itself into a man. (L VIII-18. 7630 rev., note). The lion puts its tail over its head and trots along as a man does, because it feels that it resembles a real man.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-19 or BC151_A2_1_094
Notes on chippings, or, Chipping no. 4

Remarks concerning copy of Chipping, No. 4. (L VIII.-19. 7639-7642). The dots resemble those that the people paint onto other people's heads with tto (rooiklip, or haematite). The objects in figures 3 and 7 (of the same chipping) resemble mat sieves.
The two Lions, the Lizards, the Blue Crane, the Rhebuck, and the Black Crow

The Two Lions, the Lizards, the Blue Crane, the Rhebok and the Crow. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-32. 8859-8878, 8848-8852, 19. 7643-7656). Two Lions (!gu and his companion, !haue ta =hou) kill the lizards !khau and |gi. They carry their flesh to the home of the Blue Crane and her companion, the Rhebok |ke-dde (the wives of the dead lizards), pretending to be the dead husbands. |ke-dde and the Blue Crane escape, but the Blue Crane returns home to fetch her child and is killed. The Lions find the others (|ke-dde, ||horu and |ke-dde's child), who wait for the Lions on top of a bare rock and are protected by the stones. The Black Crow draws |ke-dde up with a thong and heats stones on the ground below her house. The Black Crow throws the thong down for the Lion, and the Lion falls down onto the hot stones and dies.
|gui-an (Dootje) and her mistress, Trina de Klerk

|han=kass'o tells the story of the abuse of |gui-an (or Doortje) who was beaten by her mistress, Trina de Klerck and also by Trina's husband Jacob. Trina de Klerck had used a thong to beat |gui-an and her husband Jacob had beaten her with a heavy Bambush (bamboo) reed after which she fainted. After that beating |gui-an was unable to see properly.

Information regarding narrators family. In English after and in Bushman by /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6052 and 6053, 19. 7671, 26. 8302 rev.). Information about the younger brother of |han=kass'o's grandfather Tsatsi, called !xein (or Dirk).

Regarding some Bushman dialects. By lhan=kasso (L VIII.-19. 7672-7675). |han=kass'o comments on his understanding of other |xam dialects, spoken by 'Berg (Mountain) Bushmen' and 'River Bed people'. He can understand their language (=kakken-=kakken) even when it is different, because they are his fellows. The language spoken by another group (the |ke |ke ||en) resembles that spoken by the Nama.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-20 or BC151_A2_1_095
The rain sorcerer ||kunn; two of ||kunn's children
Information regarding //kunn was also given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-20. 7746-7749). |han=kass'o speaks of the rainmaker, ||kunn, (who he observed making rain fall) and his relations.

Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.). A man called Old Bakkis was alive when |han=kass'o went to the Breakwater Convict Station, but had died by the time he returned.

Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.). Includes the story of !kui-!kaxu (or Pained Chest) who was so named because he married a woman called Tuain-an who 'chased him with fire' and did not want him when they got married (7750v).
Concerning places and topographical features in |han=kass'o's country; his father-in-law's place is ||gubbo
Explanation of the Bushman name for a certain rock, with a description of its situation. (L VIII.-20. 7751 and 7752). Hartloof Kloof

Illness, for which the Doctor is called in, believed to be caused by butterflies. The narrators personal experience of this. Bushman children not allowed to throw stones at butterflies. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-20. 7753-7752. rev. and 7753 rev.). !gixa
The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (who may be of either sex). By /han=kasso (L VIII.-20. 7757-7762, 7768-7774). !gixa
The scene of !kaua doro and the lion

[The recto pages are not translated] The place the story occurred was shown to |han=kass'o as a child by a man called !kou (it was his place), who also told him the name of the place (which sounded like !gao-sse).

The Mantis visits the abode of the Ticks, attempts to take some of their food, and is well beaten by them. He flies away, goes into the water, and returns home where he is pitied and lectured by the Ichneumon. (L VIII.-3. 6236-6258, 6267-6269). In a further account of the Mantis and the Ticks, the Mantis pays a visit to the houses of the Ticks, is worsted by them, and escapes. Having been counselled by /kwammana, through the young Ichneumon, he goes again to the Ticks, gets the better of them, and brings their sheep home (L VIII.-20. 7790-7811). |kaggen (the Mantis) visits the Ticks, who see him coming and hide in sheep's wool. |kaggen tastes some food from one of their pots and the Ticks beat him. He flies away and returns to his house, where |kwammana tells him how to defeat the Ticks.

...the visit of //khwai-hemm (the All-devourer) to the Mantis. The latter, by means of the Porcupine, invites //khwai-hemm to visit him. He comes, and presently swallows /kwammana and the Mantis. They are rescued by young /kwammana and another child, who cut the monster open (L VIII.-20. 7812-7816, 22. 7906-7956). //khwai-hemm is stated, by /han=kasso (on the information of his mother /kabbi-an), to be the father of the Porcupine (L VIII.-10. 6934 rev., note). |kaggen (the Mantis) tells the Porcupine (his son's wife) to go to her father (||khwai-hemm), but she is afraid because there is not enough to feed him. ||khwai-hemm says that he will visit |kaggen, because he must have enough food to offer if he has invited ||khwai-hemm. ||khwai-hemm comes and |kaggen tells him to stop eating things, as there is nothing else to eat. ||khwai-hemm becomes angry and swallows |kwammana and then |kaggen. The children then each cut open a different side of ||khwai-hemm's body, and |kwammana and |kaggen fall out.|kaggen (the Mantis) tells the Porcupine (his son's wife) to go to her father (||khwai-hemm), but she is afraid because there is not enough to feed him. ||khwai-hemm says that he will visit |kaggen, because he must have enough food to offer if he has invited ||khwai-hemm. ||khwai-hemm comes and |kaggen tells him to stop eating things, as there is nothing else to eat. ||khwai-hemm becomes angry and swallows |kwammana and then |kaggen. The children then each cut open a different side of ||khwai-hemm's body, and |kwammana and |kaggen fall out.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-21 or BC151_A2_1_096
Words and sentences: |xam names of animals
A list of |xam names of animals.
Names of insects and notes on some of them (at the South African Museum)
|han=kass'o identifies and describes various insects (and some animals) found in Bushmanland.
Brachycerus The used as a means of cure for little children; the same insect not used again when another child is ill

A ceremony performed with the Brachycerus (African Ground Weevil) in order to preserve young babies from convulsions. In the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwain (L V.-23. 5833-5840) The Brachycerus used to cure illness in little children. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-21. 7822-7825). !nu !nurussi Brachycerus,
A necklace of reed used to cure a little child's cold
A reed necklace employed as a remedy for a little child suffering from a cold (L VIII.-21. 7826 and 7827). The women break and burn pieces of reed in the fire.
Names of plants and animals and notes on their use

Names of Animals (L VIII.-1. 6047-6049, 21. 7828-7830, 7834, 7836-7838, 7841, 23. 8068 rev., 8070 rev., 25. 8260 rev., 32. 8811rev., 8875 rev.). Names of Trees and Plants, and other information regarding them, given partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han=kasso. (L VIII.-14. 7219 rev. and 7220 rev., note, 18. 7552 rev.-7754 rev., 21. 7830-7833, 7835, 7847, 23. 8061 rev., 8062 rev. and 8063 rev., 8073 rev., 29. 8601 rev., 8606 rev., 8613 rev., 30. 8637 rev., 31. 8728 rev., 8790, 8791, 8789 rev.). |han=kass'o provides the names of various plants and animals found in Bushmanland, as well as notes on how they are used, and details about and descriptions of them.
Words and sentences: names of animals and other terms relating to daily life
Words and sentences given by |han=kass'o naming certain animals and common terms.
The power of cutting possessed by the reed and quartz

Stone-knives. By /han=kass'o (L VIII.-27. 8434). Reed and stone used for cutting purposes. (L VIII.-26. 8313 and 8314. The power of cutting possessed by a reed and by quartz. (L. VII.-21. 7826 rev. and 7827 rev., note). The reed is sharp and can cut and hurt people. Quartz also cuts people deeply.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-22 or BC151_A2_1_097
The song of the Mother Rhinoceros
The song of the Mother Rhinoceros (not translated), accompanied by notes on movements performed in the singing and dancing of it.
!xen (Dirk) is afraid of the female steenbok, who has a baby steenbok, and throws dust in the steenbok's eyes to make it afraid of him (as he is of it).
Dust signals, or, A man who becomes faint from the heat of the sun on his way home, throws up earth into the air, so that those at home may see the dust, and come to help him

A Bushman, who becomes faint from the heat of the sun on his way home, throws earth into the air, so that those who are home may see the dust, and come to help him. (L VIII.-22. 7961-7969 ). There follows an explanation of how the men get into the state at which they need to send dust signals. A person sends dust signals when he feels he is dying and will not reach home ('dying it is').
Notes on rock painting copy no. 2 (!nu'sa and other groups)

Remarks concerning copies of Bushman Paintings, given by Colonel Durnfold to His Excellency Sir Bartle Frere. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-22. 7969-7972, 7974 and 7975, 7983-7993, 23. 7995-8004). The mode of shooting practised by the |nusa Bushmen. By /han=kass'o (L VIII.-22. 7972-7974). |han=kass'o identifies and describes various groups of people (as they appear in a copy of rock painting no. 2).
Notes on rock painting copy no. 3

|han=kass'o describes a group of people who are fighting each other (as they appear in a copy of rock painting no. 3). A man on horseback has stabbed another. The people ask the other people for tobacco and fear the white men.
A springbok Sorcerer, named !guerriten-dde, was mentioned by /han=kass'o. !gixa'
The =gebbi-ggu, as performed among the Grass Bushmen, was described by /han=kass'o (L VIII.-22. 7978 and 7979). /goo =gebbi-gu

The Grass Bushmen. (L V VIII.-22. 7968 rev. and 7969 re., 7976 and 7977, 7980 and 7981, 7980 rev. and 7081 rev.) . A description of the Grass Bushmen and the names of places in their country. |han=kass'o saw them at a place called 'Bushlice' and at another place there called |koro-tten.
Notes on rock painting copy no. 5, no. 6. and no. 7

Remarks concerning copies of Bushman Paintings, given by Colonel Durnfold to His Excellency Sir Bartle Frere. By /han=kass'o (L VIII.-22. 7969-7972, 7974 and 7975, 7983-7993, 23. 7995-8004). |han=kass'o describes and explains copies of rock paintings (no.'s 5-7).
The slaying of a white springbok will cause the other springbok to disappear
The people of |han=kass'o's country do not kill a white springbok, because they believe that the other springbok will disappear.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-23 or BC151_A2_1_098
Notes on rock painting copy no. 8: the rain and the rain-bull

Remarks concerning copies of Bushman Paintings, given by Colonel Durnfold to His Excellency Sir Bartle Frere.-By |han=kass'o. (L VIII.-22. 7969-7972, 7974 and 7975, 7983-7993, 23. 7995-8004). |han=kass'o describes a copy of rock painting no. 8., in which there is a depiction of a rain-bull in the clouds.
Notes on rock painting copy no. 9

Remarks concerning copies of Bushman Paintings, given by Colonel Durnfold to His Excellency Sir Bartle Frere. By /han=kass'o (L VIII.-22. 7969-7972, 7974 and 7975, 7983-7993, 23. 7995-8004). |han=kass'o describes a copy of rock painting No. 9, in which he thinks that the people depicted are 'Kafirs', or black people.

||kunnu and other old men dream of rain, which speedily comes. (L VIII.-23. 8005-8010). One of the rainmakers calls to the rain, addressing it, and asks that it may fall gently and not angrily (as the old men have dreamt).

|han=kass'o relates the story of the flood at Victoria West, observed by =kuken-an and |han=kass'o's wife, Ssuobba-||ken (Sara), who were both at Victoria West at the time it happened. The rain carried all the things and the people away down the river bed and some where crushed by collapsing houses.

The people fear the rain that comes at night - it had come and flooded Victoria West, which was situated in a ravine. They make a large (male) fire in an effort to disperse the rain-clouds that gather overhead.

Clouds. Preparations to be made for the coming rain; the springbok to be watched for, etc. (L VIII.-23. 8018-8029). Jackal clouds are rain-clouds and are black. The people prepare their houses for a downpour, the men bringing bushes and the women 'making nice' the house so that they will not get wet.

Clouds. Preparations to be made for the coming rain; the springbok to be watched for, etc. (L VIII.-23. 8018-8029). The old men address the rain and the rain-clouds. The rain-clouds 'go along and are becoming black' ('jackal-clouds'). People fear the rain while on the hunting ground and desire the rain thats brings the springbok.

Horns to be burnt, when the weather looks very threatening. (L VIII.-23. 8030 and 8031). The people burn the outer layer of the springbok's horn to make the rain-clouds disperse when they see that they threaten to bring angry rain ('make war').
Young unmarried women and girls must be silent and hide from the rain
Young, unmarried women and girls must hide themselves from the rain. (L VII.-23. 8032 and 8031 rev.).
||kabbo (father-in-law of /han=kass'o) was a Mantiss man (i.e. believed to possess these insects). By /han=kass'o (L VIII.-23. 8033).
Doings of the Mantis when the eland has been wounded

An account of the doings of the Mantis when an Eland has been wounded. The protection afforded by the Mantis to the Eland is also alluded by Dia!kwain, in 'Rules to be observed when an Eland has been shot, etc.' (L VIII.-23. 8033-8039). When an eland has been wounded, |kaggen (the Mantis) is angry with the people (he 'does not love us if we kill an eland'). He does various things to trouble the man who shot the eland and thus make the eland get up and live and not die from its wounds. Also, when the people shoot gemsbok, hares appear, and if people shoot the hares then the gemsbok will recover and live.
Snake Poison. By /han=kass'o (L VIII.23. 8040 and 8041). The effects of poison from the puffadder and another animal or snake.
The Ratel and the girls of the Early Race

The Ratel (formerly a man of the Early Race (or !xwe ||na ss'o !kui) dances for the girls of the Early Race, who clap for him to continue dancing all day long. The mother of the girls becomes suspicious at their lack of success in collecting food and sends a little sister of the girls to accompany them. The Ratel dances for them and the little sister runs away, so he returns to where the elder sisters are still sitting and kills them.
A white substance and the Moon
A certain white substance found upon a bush, formerly said to proceed from the Moon. By /han=kass'o (L VIII.-23. 8040 rev., note).
The making of Clay Pots. By /han=kass'o (L VIII.-23. 8054-8067). gui

|han=kass'o describes the tactics used in hunting springbok (referring to a numbered picture), in which ostrich feathers attached to sticks are stuck into the small bushes to resemble a person and divert the herd.
The preparation of feather brushes used in springbok hunting
How the Feather Brushes used in springbok hunting are prepared and smoked. By /han=kass'o (L VIII.-23. 8073-8075, 8083 1/2 and 8083 1/2 rev.).
We do not utter a star man's name
Certain names not to be uttered. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-23. 8071 rev.). |han=kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi) told him that he should never say a star man's name (or a star's man's name).
An owl believed to foretell the coming of the lion

The coming of an owl is considered as a sign of the approach of a Lion. An insult offered by a little child, to a fly, is reported by the latter to the Lion, as disrespect shown to himself. This, the Lion waits to avenge, until the child is older. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-23. 8058 rev., 8060 rev., 8078-8080). |han=kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi) told him that an owl comes to the people when a lion is about to come to try and catch them. Also, children should not exclaim or breathe out through their nostrils in a certain manner if a fly ('lion's fly') is nearby, because it would tell the lion that a child had made light of the lion.
The lion has the power of turning itself into other things

The Lion is believed to possess the power of assuming other forms. (L VIII.-23. 8075-8077). It assumes the form of a hartebeest because it wants the people to try and head it as if it were game. It also assumes the form of a person (and wears a kaross).
Children do not say the lion's name at night
The children call the lion different names by day and by night and wish to avoid insulting (or slighting it).
A wild cat, when many have been killed by a person changes itself into a lion and kills the slayer

The Wild Cat believed to possess the power of turning itself into a lion. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-23. 8080-8083, and 27. 8399 rev., note). |han=kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi) told him that a wild cat turns itself into a lion when many of its kind have been killed by hunters.
|han=kass'o's dream of a gang of prisoners
|han=kass'o describes his dream of a group of prisoners. He mentions some of their names and describes the composition of the group.
The digging-sticks used by men are not weighted with stones. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-23. 8083 rev., note).
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-24 or BC151_A2_1_099
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-25 or BC151_A2_1_100
The story of Tssi-!kuara |hin (the Lioness and her adopted daughter)

The Lioness and her adopted daughter, Tssi-!kuara-Ihin. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-25. 8084-8169, 8171 and 8172, 25. 8173-8176). The Lioness (in the times of the Early Race) decides to keep a baby girl that she finds and names it Biting-Torn-Away (or Tssi-!kuarra |hin), and she grows up. The Lioness tricks a child into sending her brother to her at night, but his grandmothers, !kwa-!kwa and !kwa-kau, are also there (they are people and also trees). The Lioness tries to find a way of catching the young man on his own, but Biting-Torn-Away protects him and warns him how to behave around her mother. Whenever the Lioness tells a lie when she is near the fire, !kwa-!kau and !kwa-!kwa crackle from within it, causing her to move away. The Lioness kills a gemsbok and Biting-Torn-Away and the young man go to help her. The Lioness places some of the meat into a thong that she twists around her body, and asks Biting-Torn-Away to help lift her up. While Biting-Torn-Away lifts her mother's arms, the husband stabs her exposed flesh with his knife. The young man returns to his own mother's house, bringing Biting-Torn-Away with him.
Words and sentences: names of colours

Names for Colours, etc. Given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-7. 6601, 6606 and 6605 rev., 24. 8170). The names of different colours given by |han=kass'o (possibly, Lucy Lloyd thinks later in 1897, in response to a painted card).

The Man of the Early Race, whose head was of stone, the Lioness, and the Children. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-25. 8177-8197). A Lioness gathers together many of the people's children because she is an invalid and needs them to work for her. Ddi xerreten (a man of the Early Race who has a stone head) goes to her house and points out to the children the fires of their own people in different ravines, until they have all gone home.When the Lioness arrives at her house she asks Ddi xerreten where her children are and he says that they are not her children. The Lioness hurts her jaw on his stone head and is left sitting angrily at her house.
The story of |gwai (who killed his sister-in-law, and was killed by his brother-in-law)

|gwai (a person who was formerly a beast of prey and a man of the Early Race) kills his sister-in-law and his brother-in-law is angry with him and seeks revenge (the title implies that |gwai is caught and killed but it does not happen in the story).
The !gwiten who was niggardly to his wife

!gwiten The Wild Dog (or ) is stingy ('niggardly') to his wife (when they were people of the Early Race). He gives his wife the lean male pig, but takes the fat sow for himself, and she becomes thinner and thinner. She makes soup for her brothers, using the lean meat and not the fat. The Wild Dog tells his wife she must cook the sow's meat for them, because her brothers are not used to eating what she is making for them. The wife refuses.
!k'anni The is an ornament worn by men and women
!k'anni The is an ornament worn by men and women. |han=kass'o says they are beautiful and look like things from the sea.
An ostrich eggshell, left open, will attract snakes

The mouth of an Ostrich egg-shell not to be left open. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-25. 8234 rev. and 8235 rev.). If an ostrich eggshell is left open (not stopped up with grass), the wind blows into its open mouth and a snake will go into the empty eggshell.
The Lion, the Jackal, the Chersina angulata, and the Hyena. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-25. 8232-8251). Chersina angulata,
The youth (of the Early Race of people) who warned those at home of the approach of a Koranna commando

The youth of the early race, who saved the lives of the people at home by warning them of the approach of a Koranna war party. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-25. 8251-8261, 26. 8262-8268). A youth of the Early Race is seen by a commando of Korannas, so he acts as if he were a little child ('swaying about'). There is some debate among the Korannas as to whether to kill the child or not, but eventually they help him load up his water bottles and send him on his way. He returns home and tells his people what he has seen, and they leave for the mountains. The Korannas come, believing the people to still be there.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-26 or BC151_A2_1_101
A person who takes snuff: tobacco eats up his brains
The Bushmans opinion of snuff-taking. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-26. 8266 rev. and 8267 rev.). The |xam believe that a person who takes snuff has his brain eaten up by tobacco until it disappears.
The escape of |kannan from the Koranna commando

/kannan, who warned the people in vain of the approach of a Koranna war party, and was the only one who escaped. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-26. 8269-8285). A woman called |kannan sees a Koranna commando and returns home to warn her people. An old man insists that she has seen little ostriches and |kannan says she knows she has seen real people, but the people do not believe her. The Korannas attack them and |kannan alone survives the slaughter of her people.

Mountain Bushman. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-22. 7982 rev.-7984 rev.). Regarding Mountain Bushmen. (L VIII.-26. 8280 rev.). A note about the 'Mountain Bushmen' (!kaugen !k'e), who live in the mountain 'kloofs' (or valleys) on the side of the Tki (a river). Another group of |xam (or branch of the 'Mountain Bushmen', called the !kaugen ss'o !k'e) lives to the south of the 'Mountain Bushmen'.
!nana-an : the custom of calling to the wounded springbok
!nana-an The hunters call to make a wounded springbok die (or 'lie down') quickly (). They call out differently for gemsbok and ostriches.

Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-26. 8293-8302, 8315-8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.-10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.-1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.-31. 8770-8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen in making Arrows. Preparation thereof. (L VIII.-1. 6088-6091). The marking of Arrows. (L VIII.-26. 8289-8292). Arrow Bags. (L VIII. 30. 8663 rev., note). kwae tto

Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-26. 8293-8302, 8315-8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.-10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.-1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.-31. 8770-8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen in making Arrows. Preparation thereof. (L VIII.-1. 6088-6091). The marking of Arrows. (L VI II.-26. 8289-8292). Arrow Bags. (L VIII. 30. 8663 rev., note). An account of the making of arrows, using reeds, feathers rubbed with |kuai juice, sinew, ||kho and an arrow-head. The next day the people poison the arrows, when it is cold and the people do not perspire.

Certain serpents and tortoises supposed to be kept in store by the Rain. (L VIII.-16. 7431 rev. and 7432 rev.). For fear of arousing the wrath of the Rain, a certain kind of tortoise is not to be eaten by young unmarried men and women. The Rain to be addressed when it appears to be displeased. (L VIII.-26. 8303-8309. The manner in which the Rain is addressed by the old men. (L VIII.-26. 8304 rev. and 8305 rev., note).
ddabba-i An illustration of the use of
ddabba-i The term is used when parents educate their children so that they have understanding and do not do 'foolish actions'.

The names of those who are dead must not be uttered by the children at night. (L VIII.-26. 8310-8312). According to |han=kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi), when people die they become spirit-people. If the names of the dead (the old people) are called as if they are still alive, they will come and harm the living.

Stone-knives. (L VIII.-27. 8434). Reed and stone used for cutting purposes. (L VIII.-26. 8313 and 8314). The power of cutting possessed by a reed and by quartz. (L. VII.-21. 7826 rev. and 7827 rev., note). The people break off a piece of the reed and use it to cut already cooked meat (which is easier to cut).
Ssauken. A game played among the Bushmen, in which both sexes appear to take part. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-26. 8335-8350). It seems to resemble a dance in the people's movements.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-27 or BC151_A2_1_102
The Vultures and their elder sister

The Vultures, their elder sister (who was a girl of the early race), and her husband. By/|han=kasso (LVIII.-27. 8351-8373). The Vultures make a woman (of the Early Race) their elder sister and live with her at her house. The elder sister's husband (a man of the Early Race) scolds the Vultures for devouring all the food, and the next day his wife goes with him to the hunting-ground, where she must eat (as his sisters-in-law eat everything at home). The Vultures look for food and see a springbok lying on the ground. They eat the dead springbok, looking around them (for the husband) as they do so, and leave meat for their elder sister, who approaches.
Signs made on leaving a place

Signs made by Bushmen in order to show the direction in which they have gone. By /han=kasso.(L VIII.-27. 8374-8386). If a member of the group goes off and does not return in time, the others make marks (acting as pointers) in the earth by pushing their feet along the ground, and if they are travelling away they place grass near these marks. In a second part of the account, |han=kass'o decribes the manner in which branches are 'reversed' and arranged upside down (green tops in the ground) in a certain manner pointing to where the people have gone.
Others living north of the Orange River

Concerning certain Kafirs from the northern side of the Orange River. (L VIII.27. 8387-8390). The black people ('Kafirs') in |han=kass'o's country live to the north (or the 'other side') of the Orange River. He calls them 'Kaal Kafirs' and describes some of their customs and doings.

Mat sieves said to be generally made by the Bushmen, but skin sieves by the Grass Bushmen and the Koranna-Hottentots. In English, after Dia!kwain (L V.-25. VI note). Sieves supposed also to be used by the early race. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-27. 8391 and 8392). !yuiten !haken
The story of !ko'-g !nuin-tara, or, !ko'-g !nuin-tara and the Day's Heart star

The Story of !ko-g!nuin-tara, wife of the 'Dawns-Heart' Star. By /han=kasso (L VIII.--7. 8393-8432). In a note, in English, after the same narrator, the younger sister of !ko-g!nuin-tara is stated to belong to the Early Race (which preceded the Bushmen in their country), (L VIII.-6. 6546 rev., note). The She-Hyena (who is jealous of !ko'-g !nuin-tara and her child) poisons !ko'-g !nuin-tara and she becomes a Lynx and trots away into the reeds. The She-Hyena adorns herself in !ko'-g !nuin-tara's ornaments and marries the Day's Heart star. The Day's Heart asks why his wife is not attending to the child. The younger sister goes to !ko'-g !nuin-tara so that she may feed her child, but !ko'-g !nuin-tara's memory of who she is becomes increasingly vague, and she advises her sister to no longer come. Meanwhile, the Day's Heart has discovered the deception and goes to his wife in the reeds. She charges out of the reeds, but stops for one of the goats that they have brought with them. The people hold her down and anoint her with goat's blood and she is returned to normal, except for her ears which remain long and pointed so that she can retain her good hearing.

A certain small portion of the flesh of the Hare is refrained from by the Bushmen. In English, after /han=kasso (L VIII.27. 8398 rev.). The people believe this flesh is from the days when the Hare was formerly a person.

The Wild Cat believed to possess the power of turning itself into a lion. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-23. 8080-8083, and 27. 8399 rev., note). |han=kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi) told him that when the wild cat is killed and brought home, it turns into a lion and comes to kill the hunter who killed it.
Dead people are those who rode the Rain

The Rain believed to be ridden by sorcerers. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-27. 8399 rev. and 8400 rev., note). |han=kass'o was told by his elders that dead people (who come out of the ground) are those who 'rode the Rain' (when living) and thus do so again (they are rain-sorcerers).
Manner of carrying a young baby in use among Bushman women. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han=kasso (L VIII.27. 8406 rev., note).

kko in Names given to animals by the |xam, including notes on who uses them (men or women, children and so on). This includes the anteater (its other name), the springbok, the ostrich, the eland (called 'meat' by men), and the hartebeest. This story also includes information about a man whom |han=kass'o knew, who possessed 'leanness' (or ).
Making knives out of different types of stone, which are used for cutting.

The making of Clay Pots. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-23. 8054-8067). Fragments of Pottery. (L VIII.-27. 8436 and 8437). |han=kass'o describes and identifies a broken clay pot. He believes it has been used to boil meat.
Details about various people known by |han=kass'o

Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.). The information includes comments regarding their relationship with |han=kass'o, places in Bushmanland, and the names of white men (farmers). Also includes information about the death of a man called ||khwih.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-28 or BC151_A2_1_103
What is done by the Bushmen (men and women) in an eclipse of the sun
What Bushmen do when an eclipse of the sun takes place. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-28. 8438-8441). They strike sticks together, as well as shoes, to make the sun come out.
The Moon not to be laughed at

The Moon is not to be laughed at. By /han=kasso (L VIII--28. 8441-8443, 8446). People say that the Moon becomes angry when they laugh at it. People thus call it |kuan ttu to show it respect to try and keep it from going into the sky. The Moon's wife is ||ko'on.
The Moon in search of his wife. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-28. 8443-8445). The Moon returns home and finds that his wife ||ko'on is not there.

Prayer to the Stars. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-28. 8447-8449). Prayer of the narrators grandfather to the star Canopus. (L VIII.-28. 8452-8458). People pray to the stars so that they will be able to see game (that their dogs will kill for them) on the hunting-ground at night.

The stars call out 'Tsau! Tsau!'. The people say that the stars are cursing the springbok's eyes for them. When the stars came out, |han=kasso's grandfather Tsatsi prayed to them, asking to exchange his hungry heart with the star's satisfied one so he might also be filled up.

The winds which are supposed to appertain to different persons. (L VIII.-28. 8459-8465). After the wind has blown and dies, the place becomes warm from the sunshine (its 'eye' is warm). The wind becomes cold when a man kills an animal (the killed thing's wind) and the people say that his wind is cold. When it is hot the wind is gentle and not strong like the other.
Rain washes out a dead man's footsteps

Rain follows death. The method of protecting the grave. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-28. 8465-8467). When a person dies the rain falls, washing away their footprints ('a person who rains'). The people cover the grave with bushes, after which they heap stones 'nicely' on top of the bushes to cover them.
|han=kass'o's step-grandmother (Ttuai-an) joyfully adressed Canopus and Sirius when there was enough food to eat.

Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwain (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607). Also, by /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6092 and 6093, 28. 8470). ssuen ssuen
Making fire with two pieces of sticks; and tinder-making

Making fire with two pieces of stick. By /han=kasso (L VIII. -28. 8471 and 8472). The people make fire (when they have no tinderbox) using two pieces of stick (from a divided arrow). The tree used for tinder is a dry Doornboom (thorn tree) that lies dead on the ground.

. |han=kass'o describes a military parade (at the Grand Parade in Cape Town)The soldiers (British) are standing in rows. He describes their manoeuvres ('they stood still, stood in rows') as well as the movements of a dog which eventually left the parade and returned home.
!kotta-kkoe, his brother, ostrich eggs and Korannas

The two brothers, of the Early Race, who collected ostrich eggs, and were chased by Koranna-Hottentots. By /han=kasso (L VIII.28. 8486-8506). A story of the Early Race about a man called !kotta-kkoe who always swallows the ostrich eggs he finds, instead of putting them away. !kotta-kkoe's younger brother is more sensible and puts away the eggs in his bag. They run away from some Korannas, but !kotta-kkoe's stomach tears open from the weight of the eggs and his entrails fall into the river. !kotta-kkoe calls out to the Korannas to stop trying to kill him, as he is already dying from the huge hole in his stomach. The Korannas go after the younger brother and !kotta-kkoe draws together the edges of his stomach with a Driedoorn branch and escapes with his brother.

A young man of the Early Race marries =nerru (also a person of the Early Race). They are out collecting 'Bushman rice' and fill their bag, so the husband asks |nerru to use her kaross. She does not want to and he snatches it away from her. =nerru's bowels come pouring down. She replaces her bowels and returns to her mother's house. Her husband comes along looking for his wife, but =nerru's mother is angry with him for his lack of understanding.
=nerru A description of the bird (in contemporary times).
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-29 or BC151_A2_1_104
!yoa-ka-ttu, the Blue Crane and the girls
!yoa-ka-ttu, the Blue Crane, and the Girls of the early race. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-29. 8526-8554). !khi
Difference between |xam and European methods of articulation
The |xam talk with the body of their tongue, whereas the Europeans speak with the tip of their tongue.

!nu!numma-!kuiten, who fetches crying children. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-29. 8555-8560). Parents threaten their misbehaving children with !nu !numma-!kuiten (or 'White Mouth'), who kills children who cry.
Spoken of a parrot in the village of Mowbray
How a parrot can make the lateral click like a person. (L VIII.29. 8556 rev., note). A parrot seen by |han=kass'o in Mowbray sounds like a person, because it can make the lateral click.
The Anteater, the young Springbok, the Lynx and the Partridge

The Anteater, the young Springbok, the Lynx, and the Partridge, by lhan=kasso (L VIII.-29. 8561-8602). An Anteater (a person of the Early Race) steals a female Springbok child and disappears into her hole. The Lynx tells the young Springbok (named !khoukau) that the Anteater is not her real mother and they leave together, but the Partridge sees them and tells the Anteater. The Anteater follows after the two, under the ground, popping her head up sometimes to see where they are. The Lynx makes a loop with his bowstring and throws it around the neck of the Anteater, pulling her from the ground. The Anteater curses the Lynx, saying that he shall be a Lynx and go about by night. The Lynx curses the Anteater, saying that she shall be an anteater by night.
The song of the Springbok mothers
What the Springbok mothers sing when they are soothing their Springbok children.
The Quagga who was poisoned by her husband, !kuin'ssi-|kauoken

The Quagga, who was poisoned by her husband, !kuinssi/kauoken. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-29. 8603-8614, 30. 8615-8627). The Tortoise takes a piece of liver away from the baby Quagga and shares it with other animals, who agree that it tastes so good that it must be Quagga liver. They tell the young He-Dog that he must have married game and that he must kill her so that they can eat her. One of the Quagga children lets her tears fall into the cooking pots, which break. The young He-Dog marries another Quagga and the Quagga's parents hold a dance and trample the young He-Dog to death.
An illness which scratches and affects the throat which does not cause death.
Avoiding where the jackal or the hyena have passed water
Certain spots, where the jackal, or the hyena, has been, avoided by Bushmen, for fear of skin disease. By /han=kasso (L VIII.29. 8584 rev.-8587 rev.).
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-30 or BC151_A2_1_105
The Ostrich who ran away with #kainyatara and gave him as a husband to her daughter. By /han=kasso (L VIII. 30. 8628-8636). =kariten
The reason why the ostrich does not click

The reason why the Ostrich is represented as speaking without making use of click. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-30. 8628 rev. and 8629 rev., note). The ostrich does not click because its tongue is not long.

=kagara and !haunu, who fought each other with lightning. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-30 8637-8648). =kagara (a bird who was formerly a man) goes to !haunu (who is a rain's person) to take back his younger sister (!haunu's wife) and return her to her parents. There follows a fight (with lightning and thunder) and blood issuing from the nostrils of !haunu.

=kagara and !haunu, who fought each other with lightning. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-30 8637-8648). See|han=kass'o's grandmothers used to tell him that =kagara was fighting with !haunu in the east when the weather thundered and when the clouds resembled mountains and were thick.
Lightning which is black, it is that which kills us
Black lightning kills people. It comes up on them without them seeing it.
Certain kinds of food, said not to be eaten by adults
Certain kinds of food not eaten by adults. By lhan=kasso (L VIII.-30. 8649 and 8650). The |xam do not eat pigs, fish, little birds and many kinds of mice.
The Wildebeest, the Mice, the Quaggas and the Mantis, or why the (black) Wildebeest has a white or light coloured tail

The Wildebeest, the Mice, the Quaggas and the Mantis. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-30. 8651-8667). The Long-nosed Mice (who are foolish) are hunting Quaggas on the hunting-ground and the Wildebeest does several things to make their hunt unsuccessful, including trampling the Mice as the Quagga stampede. |kaggen (the Mantis) dreams of these things and talks to the Striped Mouse (who is clever). The Striped Mouse outsmarts the Wildebeest and shoots him.
The !kain who snatched off the hair of the Ostrich's head, and put it on his own head

The !kain (formerly a man of the early race, and now a little bird which is said to resemble the Lanius collaris), the Ostrich, and the Lizard. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-30. 8668-8670). The !kain snatches the Ostrich's (the toi) head-hair, because he is vain and covets it (the Ostriches are also people of the Early Race). The !khau snatches the hair and pulls it over his own head.
Agama The Lizard, the Mice and the Mantis (includes the song of the lizard)
The !khau (a lizard of the genus Agama) and his daughter, the Mice, and the Mantis. By /han=kasso (L VIII.30. 8671-8702, 31. 8703-8736). Agama
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-31 or BC151_A2_1_106
How the Bushman women show their admiration for the horse

The admiration of Bushman women for the horse. The sound of the cantering of horses imitated by them. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-31. 8737-8740). The people say that the horse canters, or dances because it feels proud on account of the women's admiration.

The admiration of Bushman women for the horse. The sound of the cantering of horses imitated by them. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-31. 8737-8740). The women sit with a rolled up kaross between their knees and slap it making the sound of the horse.

Various modes of cursing in use among the Bushmen. By /han=kasso (L.VIII.-31. 8741-8743). The people say 'Graveman!', 'Departed One!' and 'Be killed!' when cursing another man, wishing the other party to die.
The Rain-maker and Sorcerer, /kaunu. (L VIII.-31. 8759-8762, 8743 rev., 8748 rev.). !gixa
A photograph of Xu gwai reminding |han=kass'o of !nwa !koro

Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han=kasso (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.). |han=kass'o sees a photograph of a man called xu gwai who he thinks resembles a man called !nwa !koro. |han=kass'o provides the names of some of his relations and information about them.
Regarding the living again of male ostriches

The male Ostrich believed to possess the power of returning once to life. (L VIII.31. 8750 rev.-8752 rev.). The male ostrich is the one who returns to life after it has died and is called ||khabbi-ssin. The hen ostrich really dies and does not return to life.

The locusts (with the locust birds which accompany them) are set free by Sorcerers. Stones not to be thrown at the locusts. (L V.-21. 5708-5719 1/2) (L VIII.-31. 8754-8758). |han=kass'o and ||hoaken !khe were told by |han=kass'o's grandfather not to throw stones at locusts. A second part of the story concerns |kaunu who says 'locusts come out' when he wants to drive the locusts with the children.

Locust birds not to be molested; etc. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-31. 8763-8765, 8763 rev. and 8764 rev.). |han=kass'o's grandfather ordered him not to throw stones at the locust birds, for if he did the locusts (and the locust birds) would disappear.

About |han=kass'o's maternal grandfather Tsatsi (Tsa t'ssi), who was a passionate man (which is why he was never a 'sorcerer' or 'doctor'). He only ever listened to |han=kass'o's mother. Tsatsi said that his daughter had softened his heart towards the people as he would have shot at them, because they had not acted nicely in his opinion.
kuken The name of the barblet (||) on the stems of arrows that catch in the flesh of the shot animal.

//kuken, The people take a long ostrich wing feather and cut off the root to make a or barblet, that makes the arrow stick fast in an animal's flesh. The poison on the barblet dissolves off the barblet into the flesh.
Names of portions of the body of an animal. By lhan=kasso (L VIII.-31. 8774, 8772 rev. and 8773 rev.). |xam words and sentences, which appear to refer to parts of the body.
A partly translated story about a man hunting gemsbok, sees a transformed lion and steps on his poisoned arrow, which pierces his foot, poisoning him.
Relationships and other words (words and sentences)

Bushman terms for various degrees of relationship. Given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-31. 8788-8790, 32. 8792 and 8793, 8845-8847). Terms for various relationships by marriage. (L VIII.-12. 7067 rev. and 7068 rev., 32. 8794 rev.). Words and sentences concerning relationships and what people call their various relatives, as well as terms for plants and animals. (Some given by !nanni and Tamme.)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII-32 or BC151_A2_1_107

Bushman terms for various degrees of relationship. Given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-31. 8788-8790, 32. 8792 and 8793, 8845-8847). Terms for various relationships by marriage. (L VIII.-12. 7067 rev. and 7068 rev., 32. 8794 rev.).
How the Blue Crane vainly sought for !kuommain |ka ||kau, was killed and eaten by the Lions, and restored to life by means of one of the bones of the Mantis (Part 2)

The Blue Crane, the two Lions, and the Mantis. In this story, the Blue Crane, while searching for the Frogs husband, is killed and eaten by the Lions, and restored to life by the Mantis. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-32. 8794-8811). //yen
A note about the two Lions, !gu and !haue ta =hou. !gu eats people, but !haue ta =hou does not and is usually the one who scolds !gu about his doings.
People give each other nicknames. For example Soppie (or Hendrick) was so called (by Andries, or !kaogen-=kakken) because he poured soup down himself.
!ga ka Kkumm. The Frog's story (Or, The Frog, the Blue Crane, the Beetle, and !kuommain |ka ||kau) (Part I)

The Frog, the Blue Crane, the Frogs husband, and the Beetle. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-32. 8812-8820). A tale of the Early Race in which the Frog (!ga) marries !kuommain |ka ||kau, but is embarrassed to relieve herself in front of him. Her body swells up and the Blue Crane makes a hole which the Frog vomits into. !kuommain |ka ||kau returns home and asks where the child is (his swollen wife had appeared as if pregnant). !kuommain |ka ||kau jumps up and runs away.
The young woman who disobeyed her mother, and fell in with the two Lions (!haue ta =hou and !gu)

The Young Woman of the early race whose breast was caught in a cleft of the rock. Her escape from the Two Lions. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-32. 8821-8842). A tale of the Early Race in which a lazy young woman's breast gets stuck in the cleft of a rock. The two Lions (!haue ta =hou and !gu) approach her (intending to kill her), but she convinces them to go and drink water before eating her. She commands the water to 'Go away yonder!' and the Lions follow it in vain. She cuts off her nipple, releasing her breast from the rock, and pounds it together with !kai from the Lions' bag to make two balls which she leaves at the rock. When the Lions return they wonder where the girl has gone. Her nipple ball answers 'I am her!'. The two Lions spend the night trying to catch the girl and hurting their teeth biting at the rocks.
Birds await the death of a thing
A note describing how birds (and specifically crows) await the death of a thing by sitting opposite it.
The song of the young woman, as she returned home

The Young Woman of the early race whose breast was caught in a cleft of the rock. Her escape from the Two Lions. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-32. 8821-8842). She sings 'My nipple shall grow into shape again' so that her breast will return to the way it had been (before it got caught in the rock).
Bushman names for Stars. Given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-32. 8826 rev., 8842 and 8843, 8841 rev. and 8842 rev.). The stars (in Orion's belt) are named according to the hunting of springbok.
The Wifes Parents. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-32. 8843-8845). The way in which sons-in-law speak to their parents-in-law.

Bushman terms for various degrees of relationship. Given by /han=kasso (L VIII.-31. 8788-8790, 32. 8792 and 8793, 8845-8847). Terms for various relationships by marriage. (L VIII.-12. 7067 rev. and 7068 rev., 32. 8794 rev.). Some of these terms seem to be spoken by men or women and apply to relations of different genders and ages.
Greetings among the Bushmen (and times of the day)
Forms of Salutation used by Bushmen. By /han=kasso (L VIII.-32. 8853-8857, 8852 rev.). kuanna-i
Miscellaneous words and sentences given by |han=kass'o.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book III-1 or BC151_A2_1_125

A good many genealogical notes and portions of Bushman family history have been taken down (B II. 349, 359 rev., 360-362, 364, 365 368-373, 376; BXXV. 2352, 2412 and 2416; L III.-1. 476-506; L IV.-1. 3452 and 3453; L VI.-1. 3895 and 3896.) From some of these materials, and from other sources, twelve genealogical diagrams (in oblong double folio) have been compiled, each giving all the known ancestors of one individual, frequently extending four, and sometimes five generations back. ||kabbo (and possibly also |han=kass'o and |a!kunta) give names (|xam and other) and biographical details of their relations and some other people from their country. There are poignant notes relating how some of them died and their experiences with white people.
Genealogies: Ttono wo (who was killed by a rhinoceros)
||kabbo's maternal grandfather Ttono wo was killed by an adult rhinoceros. The names of some of Ttono wo's children are listed, with details of their personal history.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book IX -1 or BC151_A2_1_108
Philip' or Auma gives words in his language to Lloyd at the Grey library.
Words and sentences: given by Auma (Hottentot, Namaqua and Setschuana)

A 'Hottentot' (or !Ora-speaker) called Auma (Philip, or Jaco'bama) provides Lucy Lloyd with words and sentences in a !Ora dialect. This includes his other names and those of some members of his family as well as parts of the body, numbers, weapons and other items from daily life.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII -1 or BC151_A2_1_109
Words in the dialect of the !kun or so-called 'Ongova Bushmen' of Hereroland
A list of words and phrases in !kun (or the language of the Ongova of Hereroland, or present-day Namibia).
September 1st, 1879, South African Museum (from !nanni and Tamme)
!nanni and Tamme contribute words and sentences, mainly furnishing the !kun names of animals that they saw in the South African Museum as well as some other vocabulary.
Words and sentences: given by !nanni and Tamme in Mowbray

!nanni and Tamme (at Mowbray) contribute words and sentences relating to everyday life in their country. Some words have been given in Herero, but there are also references to other groups of people in the area, such as the Ovaherero and the Makoba (and what they call things).
Words and sentences: given by !nanni and Tamme

!nanni and Tamme contribute words and sentences relating to everyday life in their country. There is a lot of information regarding food, what plants and animals are eaten by the !kun, other groups in their country, and animals. There are fragments of songs and names and descriptions of celestial bodies, plants and animals, as well as a general vocabulary. |han=kass'o has provided various |xam words (often equivalents to the !kun words) on the verso pages. Some of the terms appear in other languages heard in !kun country, such as Makoba and Damara.

Tamme and !nanni both give the song of the ||ku, which they both heard from older people. !nanni heard it from a man called |kuirri, of his grandfather's people, and Tamme heard it from his uncle =namm-she. The ||ku is a small wild animal that resembles a jackal and eats ants and is found in the !kun country. Neither song has been translated.
!nanni tells the song of the !kan ||ka ||karashe. This is a small animal eaten by the !kun which scratches out food from the ground called ||kauru.
The names of some of Tamme's and !nanni's relations, living and dead.
Tamme (and possibly !nanni) describes some of the things eaten by the !kun (and in particular by his father).
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII -2 or BC151_A2_1_110
Words and sentences: given by Tamme

Tamme contributes words and sentences relating to everyday life in his country. The list includes !kun terms for weapons (especially arrows and arrow-making), parts of the body, plants and animals, cooking utensils, colours, numbers, weather, relations and words gained from contact with Europeans (such as tinderboxes and whipping). The names of !nanni's four brothers and sisters are noted and there are other references to the boys' personal experiences, including a fragment of a song !nanni sings when weeding, an occasional mention of the boys' parents, how |han=kass'o 'takes' Tamme to 'sleep', how Tamme's father is dead and so on. |han=kass'o has provided |xam equivalents for some of the !kun vocabulary and some of the notes on the verso pages are made by !nanni.
The moon, the sun and the stars
An account of the relationship between the sun, the moon and the stars, according to the !kun. It includes a description of the growth of the moon.
The names of !nanni's brothers and sisters
The names of !nanni's brothers and sisters.
Words in the dialect of the !kun or so-called 'Ongova Bushmen' of Hereroland
Words in the language of the 'Ongova' Bushmen given in May /79 at the Grey Library
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-3 or BC151_A2_1_111
Words and sentences: given by Tamme

Words and sentences contributed by Tamme (and occasionally by !nanni). They include many references to personal experiences. These include the people of their country, information about their relations and early childhood memories, as well as numerous names and descriptions of plants and animals (mostly in relation to food and eating). There are also many songs and the names of various !kun known by the boys. |han=kass'o provides many |xam equivalents to various !kun words.
The song of the sauko which is a bird with a long bill. It seems that it eats a small buck.
Tamme's own song about the ||noruko djo-djo (a kind of butterfly or moth) which he identifies in the south African Museum in January 1880. The song has not been translated.
Tamme's family and their understanding of the languages spoken in their country
Tamme and his family have seen and understand different people in their country. Tamme understands the languages spoken by the Ovambo, the Ovaherero and the Namaqua.
The song of the mother of the little buck
The song of the mother of the little buck. The mother antelope sings and cries about the loss of its kid.
=na=n'arro, The song of the or chameleon.
The song of the Ngogan-a (a little bird)
Ngogan-a, The song of the which is a little bird. The first line says it has gone away but the rest has not been translated.
The names of !nanni's mother and father and his grandparents.
The song of the !ke tsa'ba (a bird)
Different peoples and Bushmen in !nanni and Tamme's country
!ku Information about various different peoples and other groups of !kun (or ) found in !nanni and Tamme's country. There is a list of these groups of peoples and their differences and similarities.
The names of some of the plants and animals eaten by the !kun (and by !nanni and Tamme in particular). Mention is made of respecting certain animals and the consequences of eating them (see 9177v).
A song of the |kam-ssin !ku (or Sun Bushmen)
A song of the |kam-ssin !ku (Sun Bushmen) mourning the loss of a son.
The song of the !korro-ssin !ku (or Pit-making Bushmen)
) The song of the Pit-making Bushmen (or !korro-ssin !kuwho sing of the burning or pain in their eyes.
!na !na'rishe The song of the (a large bird). It sings of the disappearance of the people from its country.
The song of the ||gani (a kind of woodpigeon).
The names of !nanni's grandparents and information about them (whether they are living or not and what !kun-speaking group they belong to).
Tamme's (or possibly !nanni's) aunt was killed by elephants at night. His mother told his father who killed a person. Tamme's mother cried and the father kills another person the next day.
Tamme's father's heart aches so his mother tells his father to sleep in ashes. His father does as she says and becomes white from the ashes.

Tamme's younger brother dies so his mother sleeps outside at the back of the house. When a child dies, another child does not eat. Another child also 'must die'. When a person dies the people bury him or her in the earth.
How Tamme was taken by the Makoba and given to the Ovambo

An account of how Tamme came to be 'dispossessed' of his people. Tamme and his mother are at the Makoba village. Tamme is persuaded to go into a Makoba's house. The Makoba refuses to allow Tamme to return to his mother and people. The Makoba eventually give Tamme to the Ovambo, who hand him over to white men (9167).
Tamme's experiences before coming to Mowbray

Tamme recounts some of his experiences when younger. He describes other people he has met, such as a person called |kon-ta and his family. Tamme recalls when he was small ('so high') and his mother carried him on her back. He was able to see many things from that position. He feared the water, which was cold.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-4 or BC151_A2_1_112

The names and descriptions of some plants and animals eaten in !nanni and Tamme's country. It includes notes on whether the food is eaten raw or cooked, and what food is found in the Damara's country.
The people of !nanni's country do not make pots. The Makoba make pots and trade them with the !kun.
!nanni's mother fears the night, whereas Tamme's does not. !nanni's father does not fear the night. In the darkness (which 'sat') lions kill one of the Ovaherero's cattle and their oxen go away.
The little elephant (which fell into the game pit but did not die)
A little elephant falls into a game pit. It does not die because the mother elephant pulls it out.
Words and sentences: times, country and language
Words and sentences given by !nanni and Tamme, including times, the boys' 'country', and Tamme's language (his 'speech is one, not many'). Many of the !kun only speak one language.

When one of the !kun dies, the other people dig a hole in the earth and place the dead person inside it. When a man dies, his bow and stick are put into his grave with him. The grave is covered up with earth. Another man takes the dead man's arrows. After the people have buried the dead person they leave for another place (or 'country'). They do this because they fear or respect death and the dead person.
The names of Tamme's brothers - dead and alive
The names of Tamme's brothers. One was still living when he left his country and another three had died.
An account of an incident involving Tamme's father in which he asked a party of men for a bow. Tamme says that his father had killed a person and was killed by 'another man'.
What !nanni's father told him (what to eat and avoid)
!nanni's father (|umma-tchi-gua) told him what to eat and what to avoid. !nanni's father had been instructed by his father (Karu) in the same matters.

!goa A story in which an elephant father and mother dig out a pit for a little elephant near to a tree. The mother elephant puts the little elephant in the pit and fills the pit with earth.
