At sunset the elephant mother awakes and lifts the little elephant out of the pit. The two of them run down to the water and the mother puts the little elephant into the water.
!nanni's father wore a back-dress of genet (or sua). He also wore a back-dress of weasel (or muishond, or dda). He wore a front-dress of ||ko. When he goes away he hangs up the back-dress.
When a person dies, the !kun (!nanni's people) do not immediately leave the place of death but leave as a group on another day. In !nanni's maternal grandfather's country, the dead go into the Moon.
Words and sentences: plants and animals
!nanni and Tamme give the names of some plants and animals found in their country. This includes some information about them, as well as if and how they are eaten.

When people are ill, some of the people 'doctor' the afflicted person and stand and make various gestures. Other people sing (and do not make gestures). Other people beat the drum. Dreams put 'a thing' into a person and makes them unwell.

About the dream (or ||gan-a) of !nanni and Tamme's country. In !nanni's country a dream put 'a thing' into a person and this makes them ill. In Tamme's country, a dream speaks to him. The dream speaks to many people who hear it. The people told Tamme that when a person dies he or she becomes a dream (or ||gan-a). The dream's heart aches when this happens and kills another person (it puts a 'thing' in them).

A brief account of the making of huts, or grass houses. The people put poles into the ground after digging holes. They fix the poles firmly into the holes, putting leaves in the spaces around the poles (or sticks). They cover these over with grass and sweep the floor of their huts.
!nanni and Tamme give the names of some birds and bird's eggs found in their country. This includes some information about the birds as well as if and how they are eaten, and what they eat.
Words and sentences: plants and animals
!nanni and Tamme provide words and sentences including the names and descriptions of some plants and animals found in their country (mostly edible).

When the !kun hunt and kill an elephant they fear and respect its heart. One person alone cannot eat it and the hunter avoids eating it altogether. If the hunter were to eat the heart an elephant would kill him on another occasion. The heart is shared out amongst the other people. It takes five days to eat an entire heart. The people cook elephant heart in a pot.
Trading with the Makoba and elephant tusks

The !kun hunt elephants and then trade elephant tusks and other parts with the Makoba in exchange for food (and cattle to use as meat). A Makoba tells !nanni's people to go into 'another country' and seek and kill other large elephants to bring tusks back for him. In exchange he will give !nanni's people a small animal (a cow or calf).
Words and sentences: plants and animals (and avoiding the lion's name)

Tamme (and possibly !nanni) gives words and sentences relating to many aspects of daily life in their country (mostly to do with food). Mention is also made of the name used by !nanni's and Tamme's people when speaking of the lion (its name is avoided by the !kun).
The Lion's story, or, The Lion and the Hyena

!nanni's paternal grandfather (Karu) told him to be quiet and told him the story of the Hyena (or ||gaxa) who entered the Lion's house. The Lion had forbidden the Hyena to talk like the Lion did (the Lions talked). The Lion puts food to cook on the fire (which seems to be caterpillars). The Lion wakes the Hyena and tells it to say 'Mmmm' and eat the little caterpillars, but the Hyena says '=naa!' instead. It does not want to eat the hairy caterpillars. The Lion listens to the sounds that the Hyena makes and objects to its speech. The Lion pierces the Hyena's hindleg and it says '=naa!' several times and then '=e sho-sho!' as well and runs away.
Beating a stone on the ground

Beating a stone upon the ground protects the people from lightning. Only women beat stones on the ground. !nanni's (?) paternal grandmother did this and said 'Fall into the water!' and the lightning (or rain) fell into the water.
Tamme gives the names of his paternal and maternal grandparents, as well as his father's paternal grandfather. 'Tamme' appears to be a family name.

This is a story about |xue and his wives (!nanni says that he saw |xue, his house and child while !nanni was with the Herero). |xue resembles a lizard one day, a |ou (a small buck, probably a steenbok) the next, and a little tsema and a ||ha and a python (=ni), all on different days. When |xue dies he resembles the |ou (and has horns). As |xue lies there dead his wives see him and come and pick him up and carry him to the house. The elder (or 'greater') wife makes a fire to cook the kid, and puts his body on the fire. |xue calls out, objecting to being put on the fire. The second wife takes |xue to her house and covers him with a kaross. He bites it and becomes a kid again. The second wife kills him and puts him in a cooking pot, shutting him in and covering him. He becomes an ant and bites his second wife. His wife crushes his ant's head and throws |xue down on the ground.

An account of how two !kun (called |xue and ||namme) go into the house of a |nani. They sit down at the |nani's fire to warm themselves because it has been raining. A |nani child sees them and wakes his father and tells him that two !kun are warming themselves at the fire. The !kun men run away and the |nani father chases them and aims at them with his bow and arrow. The |nani throws an axe at the retreating men but misses them and |xue shoots and kills him instead.
Tamme's father told him about |xue, as !nanni's grandfather Karu had told him. !nanni talks about |xue but Tamme does not. Tamme gives his mother's father's name.
Words and sentences (including a note on |xue)
Words and sentences, including the name of |xue's second or younger wife, as well as the names for houses.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-5 or BC151_A2_1_113

|xue becomes a small bird (by the name of ||kouri) and is taken hold of by his child. His child's mother warns the child to leave |xue alone, but the child refuses, saying he wants to take hold of his father. The child puts |xue down on the ground and he flies up into the sky. |xue becomes a larger bird (called !kuarra, which seems to be an eagle) and his child sings out for !kuarra to 'divide my hands'. The bird flies down and grabs the child's mother's head in its claws. She angrily curses |xue saying 'let a lion take |xue!' because she wants him to vanish. The people take hold of |xue and beat him until he dies and vanishes.
An account of some of the different people found in Tamme's mother's country.
Words and sentences: things belonging to different peoples in !nanni and Tamme's country, and plants and trees

Words and sentences including the names of weapons and things belonging to different peoples found in !kun country (the Makoba, the Shimbari and the |nani). There are also descriptions and names of some edible plants, berries and trees.
The !kun call spirits (or dreams) ||gan-a. Other people in their country (namely the Makoba and the Ovaherero) call them different things when they speak of them.

|xue pours water on his sleeping wife and she curses him. His wife takes a fire-stick and beats his forehead and |xue runs off to another place where he sleeps on the ground. At sunrise the wife's father looks for |xue, calling for him as he goes. |xue rises up and his father-in-law gives him food to eat. |xue goes with his father-in-law to his house where |xue's wife waits. She says that he had resembled many different things while he was gone and that she had seen him. He had been a man at sunset and a lizard at sunrise. She warns him that he will get killed by another man when he goes in this form into another country.
|xue becomes a buffalo. In this form he eats grass and his wife sees him. [incomplete]

|xue becomes an ostrich and goes into a rock. He becomes an owl and dies and flies eat him. |xue's wife carries him to her house. She fetches a large pot and puts him in the pot, pours water on him and builds a great fire, intending to cook him. |xue cries because he is afraid of the fire and his wife asks if it is her husband who cries. |xue's wife breaks the pot and |xue says 'I say |xue', revealing himself. |xue's wife cries.
|xue is a spirit, and kills his child

|xue becomes a spirit and kills his child. |xue's wife goes out and when she returns to the house she sees the dead child there and accuses |xue of killing it. She takes a fire stick and burns |xue with it. |xue cries out, runs away and climbs a tree. The sun sets and rises and sets and rises again and |xue descends the tree. |xue's wife speaks to her father who goes out searching for |xue and when he finds him he slaps |xue and then carries him home. There |xue's father-in-law throws a stick at him and |xue runs away. |xue becomes a little snake and bites the father-in-law, who cries out and then dies. |xue becomes a large fly and flies away, and as he does so the father-in-law rises again. |xue becomes a butterfly and then becomes |xue the man again. When he sees his wife's father alive again carrying a big stick he runs away. [The ending is inconclusive.]
!nanni and Tamme belong to different groups of !kun. Tamme is one of the Yabbi and his country was the Tsaba. !nanni was a ||no and his country was the Kaku i ra.

sa The Hai-||umm resemble the !kun. They speak the same language as the Berg Damaras and also speak !kun and the !kun understand their language. The Hai-||umm's country is near that of the !kun. The !kun buy something called from them.
!gau The grasshopper of !nanni's and Tamme's country (called the ) eats small grass flowers. The little grasshopper eats the blades of the grass and the large grasshopper eats the stems.
|xue as a ||gui tree and a fly

At sunset |xue becomes |xue and lies on the ground and sleeps on his own. At sunrise he awakens and sees the sun and becomes ||gui (a tree). His wife sees the ||gui and picks some of its fruit. The ||gui vanishes and |xue becomes a fly instead. |xue's wife is upset about the ||gui vanishing and lies on the ground to cry. |xue in the form of the fly settles on the grass (called go o).

In this story |xue becomes an ant, a butterfly, a fly, water, a buffalo, a snake, a tsan, a ||xuonna and a bird. |xue chases his wife in a variety of forms and eventually dies. His wife picks him up and puts him inside her kaross, but drops him when he becomes a ||xuonna. She goes on into her father's country. In another part of the account (also told to !nanni by Karu) |xue also becomes !naxane, an owl, a fly, a bee, a hyena and, finally, an ant. As a bee he bites and kills his father. |xue performs a doctoring ceremony and his father rises up and chases |xue. |xue and his father fight. Eventually, |xue settles on his father's head and he dies. |xue's father takes him off his head and sets |xue down on the ground, where he becomes an ant.
!nanni's paternal grandfather Karu tells him that the doings (or works) of |xue are numerous and not one, but many.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-6 or BC151_A2_1_114

|xue is water, a lizard, grass, a |nu-erre bird, a dead elephant, a buffalo, a tsan, an Omuherero and a snake (a ||ge). |xue makes reeds at the water and grabs one of the woodpigeons. |xue becomes |xue and rises up and grabs the bitten woodpigeon and plucks out its feathers, putting them on his head. |xue puts the woodpigeon's body on hot embers and eats it. He hears an Ovaherero and hides. |xue flies away to his mother's country where he sees his father. |xue's mother and father become afraid of him and run away. |xue chases his father, all the while loudly speaking the Berg Damara language. |xue fears the large black reeds where his father hides. |xue sits and drinks water from a little hole and cries for his father. His father sees him, but leaves because |xue is an Omuherero. |xue searches for his father and cries when he does not find him.
|uma and Da: the names of their parents
The names of |uma's and Da's parents. |uma's father's name is ||e-|kue and his mother's name is ||kabbe-!!ne-a (?). Da's father's name is |xoa-ku and his mother's is ||xauti.

!gauka |xue's father (|xe ||n'u) sees a bird (called ) and |xue goes to look at it and dies. His father carries him back to his mother's. At sunset |xue arises and calls out to his father. When he comes running to |xue, |xue dies and changes into a mouse. When his father sees him he takes an arrow and shoots him. |xue gets up and chases his father. |xue's mother beats his father on the head with a stick. |xue and his father fight and die and shoot at each other.

|xue bites his father, breaking his father's finger. |xue's father goes away. |xue becomes a shana (the fruit of a small tree). The rain falls on him, and he lies down and cries when the rain is over. His father hears him and throws him over his shoulder. |xue cries very loudly so his father puts him down and he follows his father. |xue grabs a little |ou (a little buck, probably a steenbok) from some birds (!kuara). |xue's father roasts some of the meat and leaves for his own country. |xue sits at the fire and cries for his father to carry him. |xue hears his father's laughing and gets up, crying. He becomes rain and tells the rain to pour down on his father. |xue's father beats |xue and tells his wife to give |xue to another person so they can kill him. |xue hears this and cries and his father leaves. |xue follows his father and at sunrise he becomes !naxane. |xue's father puts two of the !naxane into his bag. |xue changes back to |xue and |xue's father searches for the !naxane. |xue climbs a !gua tree and refuses to come down, being afraid of being beaten. |xue's mother slaps him so that he falls from the tree. |xue becomes a lizard (gora) and then a bird (called ||kanna-tatta). [It says 'to be continued' on page 9489v, but it is not clear where the story is taken up.]
!nanni recites a prayer to the young moon. The people pray to the moon so that they may find food and eat.

A (violent and lengthy) account of what happened after the death of !nanni's uncle (|un'ta), who died in the Makoba's house. Karu cries for his dead child. !nanni's father, ya ||ne, tells his father to be silent, as does Karu's wife. ya ||ne and Karu's wife beat Karu with a stick until people take hold of ya ||ne. ya ||ne and Karu threaten and attempt to kill each other a number of times and Karu threatens to kill his own wife. Karu's wife's father (||namme) beats Karu. Karu shoots his father-in-law in the head with an arrow. Karu runs away and the people chase him. Karu's wife beats him and he aims his arrow at his wife. Karu's people beat him with knobkerries.
Pieces of wood for divining, or |xu

A description of the set of wood pieces (or |xu) used by the !kun for divining. This set of pieces is said to assent 'to me about the thing'. The set consist of four pieces - two male and two female. The Makoba call the set |nu |num, although the boys say it is a 'Bushman institution'.

The !kun (particularly women) call the young moon `!ka !karrishe and blow on the horn of a male |ou (a small buck, probably a steenbok). The young moon points out food to the people (for example bees). This story includes Karu's prayer to the moon, in which he asks it for food ('Tell me of things, that I may eat!'). At sunrise the man (possibly Karu) goes out and kills a lizard that the moon has shown him. The wife cooks the lizard and fetches a dish to cut it up in. The man gives his wife the lizard's head to eat and she cries loudly. The man beats his wife and threatens to kill her. The wife does not speak to him because she is afraid.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-7 or BC151_A2_1_115

|xue, both his wives and his child inflict various forms of violence on each other. In the course of the story |xue becomes a number of people all at once to beat his wives and child. When he has died, |xue's father makes a grave for |xue. |xue's father and father-in-law put |xue into the grave. |xue cries out for them to leave him alone. |xue's father-in-law burns his eyes with fire and his mother beats |xue's father-in-law with a stick. The father-in-law shoots |xue's father with an arrow, killing him. |xue lies on the ground crying for his dead father. At sunset |xue's father returns to life and pursues |xue to beat him. |xue's father ties him up in a skin and carries him home. |xue's mother tries to give |xue food but his father says she must not. |xue lies silently on the ground and then shoots his father. |xue, his father and his mother continue to beat each other up. |xue goes into a mouse-hole and bites his father, breaking his 'first fore-finger'. |xue's father beats |xue as he runs into the mouse-hole, breaking off a horn that he has tied to his back. [This story should have been continued elsewhere, but appears not to have been.]
A few words and sentences given by !nanni and|or Tamme in January 1880.

!naxane Karu did not speak of |xue at night, but only in the daytime. When Karu told !nanni (during the day) about the doings of |xue, !nanni was afraid of |xue and cried. Karu put into a dish and !nanni stopped crying and sat down to eat it.

When a !kun man dies, his things are not given to another person. This would make the deceased's wife cry and the people afraid ('we should tremble'). There follows an account of the interaction between the dead person's child (son) and wife.
An account of what is done with the body of a deceased man and how it is dressed and arranged (by his father).
The pieces of wood used by the Bushmen of !nanni's country for divining future events

The !kun use wooden pieces called |xu for divining future events. These pieces are made of wood from the !ke tree (also a 'food' tree). Women do not touch these pieces but men can. Little girls also respect (or 'fear') these sets of pieces. A mother tells her daughter to respect the pieces, which she does. Little boys do not fear the pieces and are allowed to handle them.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-8 or BC151_A2_1_116
A few words given by Da in October 1882.
Poisons and a description of gathering them

Kai Tamme and !nanni name and describe poisons used by the !kun, most of them taken from trees and plants. There are many poisons. The poisons are prepared (often boiled in a pot) and put onto arrows to shoot game. The people also gather caterpillars called from large trees, with which they make poison. !nanni describes one of these excursions to gather this poison by his people. His father and grandfather (Karu) were on this excursion, and Karu was injured during the outing.
|xue as !naxane and butterflies and with people who are afraid

|xue is at the top of a large palm tree and asks his wife to cut off his ears (it seems that the wind is loud and frightens him). She refuses and says that he is not her husband, because her husband is a man. She runs away from him. |xue goes searching for the woman (his wife). He cries and calls for her as he goes, and when his wife hears this she returns to him. |xue threatens to kill his wife if she runs away again so she runs off crying out in fear for her life. |xue chases after his wife and later makes an earthen house and lies there to sleep. The rain falls on |xue and then stops, and the Moon rises. |xue awakes and leaves the hut to sleep on the bare earth. [It says 'to be continued' on page 9626, but appears not to have been.]
The Moon and the Hare and |xue

U'we (or |xue) creates things (including food animals). The Moon says that the people shall return again from death (and not die outright). The Moon tells the Hare that the Hare's dead son will return to life, but the Hare objects, saying that his dead son smells bad. |xue laughs at the Hare and beats him. The Moon tells |xue to leave the Hare alone, but |xue ignores the Moon. The Hare's wife beats |xue. The Moon tells the She-Hare to leave |xue alone, but she tells the Moon that she will kill |xue for beating her husband. The male Hare gets up and kills |xue, who does not die outright. The Moon kills |xue a number of times, but he does not die outright. The Moon and his wife threaten each other. The Moon's wife tells the Moon to kill |xue, but the Moon is afraid.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-9 or BC151_A2_1_117
Words and sentences: names of animals given by Tamme at the museum
Tamme (and occasionally !nanni) provides Lloyd with the !kun names of animals, birds and insects at the South African Museum.
The people in Tamme's country respect the mantis (||gan-a) and do not eat it. A person who eats the mantis dies.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-10 or BC151_A2_1_118
|xue and the bam-bam, and as other things

|xue is afraid of a large bam-bam bird and becomes (or makes) a leopard (!khumm). Woodpigeons, an owl, a korubo and some ||kuorres (small mouse-like animals with cat-like eyes and tail) all laugh at the leopard. The leopard stalks a number of animals and searches for the carcass of a bam-bam bird. At sunset the leopard becomes |xue again and lies down to eat shana. He walks to the water, which is far off. He drinks all the water and shoots a young |ou (a small buck, probably a steenbok), breaking its foreleg. When |xue tries to shoot again his bow breaks. |xue goes to sleep on the bare ground and then makes a new bow from a stick.
Tamme describes what wild animals are eaten by the !kun.
!nanni recites a verse relating what is said by the lion. In it, the lion tells the people to stop laughing at it and to respect it.
Words and sentences provided by !nanni and|or Tamme.

A description of the coming of the rain and the appearance of ||kum'm, or great black clouds. The rain in the boys' country affects the falling of the flowers and the behaviour of the caterpillars on the trees.
!gauru A description of the drum (called ) made and played by the !kun.
!ha A description of the making of 'wells' (or ) in !nanni and Tamme's country. They say that the water has 'one root', which refers to the well in Mowbray.
The !kun terms for people who are intelligent (their thoughts are not absent) and foolish (their thoughts are wanting).
Little girls do not eat the |no, and respect it. Adult women do eat it (its head, its body and the bones).
An account of how women 'work', or cut themselves. Men cut (or bleed) themselves between the eyes with a knife. The blood is caught in a cup made of animal horn, held by another person.
The !kun do not 'throw away' their old people, but keep them with them. The old people take care of the small children when the mothers are off collecting food.
Words and sentences: plants and animals
!nanni and|or Tamme give the names of plants and animals found in their country, as well as other words and sentences from their daily life.
The names and descriptions of some of the different seasons in !nanni and Tamme's country.

!naxane |xue pours water into his pot and carries it on a stick over his shoulder (he has attached an ox-head at the other end of the stick). He trips and wounds his knee and the pot breaks. He leaves the ox-head in the tree and departs for his mother's country with a bag of . The people hide from |xue. |xue searches for his people in vain, and turns back crying.
Tamme explains that his people respect the eland ('with certain observances').
The |nu'she, the tt' e, and the wind and rain

The |nu'she (a small black bird) calls when the sun is small and has not risen (it is in the ground). When the wind blows hard the rain comes, and the wind ceases when the rain falls. While the people eat the !naxane, the tt' e (a fowl-like bird) calls. These birds also eat !naxane.
The widow married by her dead husband's next brother

When a woman's husband dies, the widow is 'taken' by the dead man's younger or next brother. In this way her children are brought up with a father ('nicely'). When this man also dies the wife lies down and sleeps alone. Her son goes away and marries and the widow has to rely on her daughter to give her food, wood and water. A man comes to take her daughter away to live as his wife in another country.
A man respects his wife's mother

=khumm A man respects his mother-in-law's name and does not speak it. His mother-in-law addresses him as 'son-in-law'. When his mother-in-law is silent he is silent. He addresses his wife's father as his .
Killing a wife by means of a poisoned arrow in her bed

!kun husbands kill their wives by placing a poisoned arrow (a |nu'bbo) upright in her bed. The husband tells the crying mother to stop crying, as his actions were justified. The mother-in-law says she will mourn her daughter for many days and will not listen to a 'stranger' who has killed her daughter. The husband says that he will kill his mother-in-law if she does not consent to go away.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-11 or BC151_A2_1_119

An account of the methods favoured by the !kun in dealing with theft among their people. If a woman steals and her parents are alive she is given over to them and taken away to their country. The husband returns the stolen item and beats or kills his wife. Another part of the account deals with children that steal. If an orphaned female child living with others steals, her foster family gives her to the person from whom she stole. They put her in a hut where they burn and kill her. In another part of the account a man who has stolen is shot with many arrows. Men are shot and women are burned. If a child steals the child is scolded but not killed. If that child grows up and then steals, it is killed.

A story about stars and some of their doings. The star has small arms and no horns. It is a small thing. When the 'darkness sits' or night falls, the star runs off into the sky. The children pull the star from the earth and play with the star. The children take it up and then throw it away. In this way the children kill the star. When stars fall to earth they die.
The bird called by the !kun Goba-|nua-me
The Goba-|nua-me ('Makoba-boils-me') bird is so called by the !kun because they believe it is crying 'The Makoba boils me'. Its appearance and habits are described.
The |nu'she bird calls at sunrise. There is a description of its appearance and call.
dzana The taps on dry trees. It frightens away other animals who think its tapping is made by people.
Terms for being alive or not quite dead
A short piece describing the different states of being alive, or not 'quite' not dead, or 'quickly dead'.
=xo gure A description of the bird, which is eaten by the !kun (Tamme in particular).

A description of an edible plant called the |khoro. It grows on the ground and the root is cooked in the fire. The birds eat the fruit. Certain practices relating to phases of the moon are observed when eating this or the =gue-||na plant. There is a description of the two plants and where and how they grow. Their stems climb trees and are long, but the edible parts of the plants are short. Both of these plants can be harmful if eaten at the wrong time.
!nanni's grandfather Karu told him about Hu'-we, who is a !kun. 'Hu'-we' is what the !kun call a person who works many things, and the people also call him |xue.
The Hare, |xue, the Antelope and the Bushman: a creation legend

According to Tamme's people, |xue is Hu'-we and also the Hare (who creates things). The Hare puts the person he has made into an antelope-skin bag (there are four bags and four kinds of people, each speaking different languages). He takes one bag of people and throws it far away. He throws a bag of thread or string far away so that the people may catch and eat antelope. At sunrise |xue comes to him and says that the Hare is a mere hare and must behave like a mere hare. The Hare says he is also |xue and speaks !kun (he says this somewhat peevishly, as he seems to feel that he has been doing so all along). |xue tells the Hare to put food into a bag for the people, but the Hare refuses to feed them, saying |xue must do so with his own food. |xue throws bags with food and with a bow and arrows to the !kun's country and tells them to shoot the Hare.

An account of the procedure followed when a man kills another man. The man who has shot another does not eat or drink water for two days (he has 'done without two things'). On the third day he performs a cleansing ritual, which is described in detail.
What the man says while cleansing himself

The man who is cleansing himself (after shooting and killing another man) takes |kui fruit in his hands and speaks, saying that his heart must be calm and does not burn. The father-in-law says words that are intended for the relations of the man who has been killed.

The man who is cleansing himself (performing a purification ritual, or |koa) puts some |u' ||ke (from the |u' ||ke' plant) into the |kui food he has cooked on the fire. He scrapes a little into the food. After eating it he lies down. The |u' ||ke' plant intoxicates people.

The |u' ||ke'. or Tshaka, is a small plant and is used as part of the purification ritual, or |koa. It intoxicates and can kill people if handled incorrectly (at the wrong time of day), and is thus feared. The =nabbi does not kill people and is given when the people 'seek their hearts'. Both plants seem to be effective at specific times of day.
The manner in which a man who is being cleansed, is prepared for drinking water

During purification (or |koa) the man being cleansed is prepared for drinking water. His father squirts water over him (on his chest and back) from his own mouth. The man being cleansed then drinks water given to him by his father. The man drinks water, but does not eat (the man is allowed to eat 'water food', or water plants, or tcha, if there are some there, and if the appropriate preparatory ceremonies have taken place, given by his father or another 'proper' person). The man must abstain from food for two days but does not abstain after he has been cleansed.
Further particulars regarding the purification or cleansing (|koa)

A description of further aspects of the purification or cleansing ritual (|koa). The father (of the man who has killed another) blows smoke onto his son's back and chest and then gives him some to smoke. He warns his son not to smoke Indian Hemp until he has been cleansed.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII-12 or BC151_A2_1_120
A certain snake, which, by lying upon its back, announces a death in the family; and must not, in these circumstances, be killed

The |||hin is a snake found in !nanni's country which announces death if it lies on its back. If the snake turns over when struck, the people immediately leave it alone and return home. If the snake does not roll over when struck, the people kill and skin it and trade the skin with the Makoba. The snake appears when a person has died and the news has not yet reached other people.
A snake found near a grave

The people of !nanni's country do not kill the snake that is found near a grave, because the snake is the dead person's snake and it is the spirit of the dead. Similarly the people do not kill other animals (such as antelope and lizards) which are found near graves. They are considered to be spirit-animals or spirits of the dead.
Snakes and spirits of the dead

People become spirits when they die. A dead man has a mere spirit as well as an other which is a snake. Spirit-animals live near graves. If a man dies he becomes a snake. Men also become snakes when bitten by them ('and his snake is a spirit'). If a woman dies she becomes a mere spirit unless she dies of a snakebite in which case she becomes a snake. Mere spirits go away.
Tamme provides a short account concerning a Makoba who goes to his country when it rains. The Makoba say they see a rainbow and the rain falls.
!nanni and Tamme give the !kun equivalents of some questions.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI-1 or BC151_A2_1_121
End of Moon and Hare story
!nanni concludes the legend of the Hare and the Moon in which the Hare has told the Moon that the people and others must really die.

The Moon instructs the Sun to go to a certain place. The Moon says that he is the Moon and that he and the Sun do not listen to the Hare. The Hare is torn between laughter at the Moon's beauty and tears for those who die outright. The Hare and his wife quarrel and the Moon becomes heartsore and vanishes, making the night very dark. The She-Hare calls her husband who steals up to her in the form of a jackal and catches her. The Moon seizes the Hare and rips off his jackal-skin, which he gives to the jackal. The Hare insists that he is a jackal. [It says 'to be continued' at the bottom of page 10117 but it is not clear where this occurs.]
|kui A note referring to !nanni's drawing of the fruit, which describes how it is eaten and prepared when ripe and unripe.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XIII & XIV-1 or BC151_A2_1_122
Words and sentences: |uma at Mowbray, May 1880

|uma provides words and sentences at Mowbray in May 1880. These include parts of the body, some biographical information, things eaten in his country and the names and some descriptions of various plants.
Words and sentences: |uma and Da at Mowbray
|uma and Da provide words and sentences at Mowbray. These mostly include terms from everyday life, such as objects of use and parts of the body.
|uma: his capture by the Makoba and his Boer masters

|uma relates his personal experiences and his capture by the Makoba. The account includes his meeting with Da, and describes the travels of the two boys with a series of 'masters' and their journey to the Cape.
|uma tells of his experiences with a ghost (or ||gaun-a).

When one of the !kun dies, the people dig a grave and put the dead person into it. The body is covered in earth and the grave is filled in. A tree is cut down and laid over the grave. |uma relates the death of one of his relatives who was killed by an arrow. His people put the relative into the earth and the women cried for him. If a stranger is killed they do not bury him. The account includes mention of how tobacco is shared with a stranger. If the man returns with none to share he is killed.

Words and sentences provided by Da in May 1880 (and added to in October 1881). The other boys have also added various explanations, corrections and notes which Lloyd has noted on the verso pages and throughout some of the text. Da has provided the names of parts of the body, details of practices and objects he encountered in his daily life, and the odd detail relating to his experiences (and capture) and his parents and relations (before he was taken away from them). Da also gives the names for parts and markings of arrows and their uses, as well as the names of other implements and weapons used by his people. Da also mentions some of the other peoples found in his country (such as the Makoba and the Damara) and some of his people's experiences with them.
Da: his capture and the death of his parents

Da describes his capture by the Makoba and the deaths of his parents and other members of his family. The Makoba came and took Da in his country. The Makoba put the children into the water where it seems they were eaten by alligators (crocodiles). Da escaped this fate and was not put in the water.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XV-1 or BC151_A2_1_123

Lloyd takes down information and personal details from four prisoners at the Breakwater Convict Station on 17 April 1880. The four men were |nu'xa (or Hans), Mkuan (or |kabbeten, his |xam name), Mosunyan, and Molef. The information noted includes their prisoner numbers, the names of their relations, some measurements, and personal details about the men.
Words and sentences: Mkuan at the Breakwater

The prisoner Mkuan provides Lloyd with words and sentences at the Breakwater Convict Station in April 1880, including details of his personal history. He also provides the names for parts of the body, plants and animals, and other objects and elements from daily life.
The |xam names of some of Mkuan's relations
Mkuan gives the names of some of his relations, namely his paternal grandfather and two of his children.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XVI-1 or BC151_A2_1_124

!nauxa (or Willem) is accompanied by his !Ora, or Hottentot, companion, !khannumup (or Petros Willems). He tells Lloyd his mother's and father's names, the name of his people ('Grass Bushmen', or |nu'sa'), the names of some mountains near his country, and other personal details. The two men were photographed by Hermann, apparently on the same day of the interview, at the South African Museum.
Words and sentences: at the Museum, 24 September 1880 (!nauxa and !khannumup)

!nauxa and !khannumup (at the South African Museum) give words and sentences in |xam (on the recto pages) and in !Ora ('Hottentot') on the opposite pages. These are largely the names of plants and animals and some descriptions of their habits or appearance.
Lloyd notes some personal information about !khannumup (or Petros Willems) including the names of his relations, his place of origin and his wrongful imprisonment.
Memo for Miss Lloyd' (regarding some personal details of 'Petros Willems' and 'Willem') (a copy)
Lloyd copies a memo from Mr A. Martin in which he has noted !nauxa and !khannumup's measurements, and other details of their personal information and history.
Covers of Lloyd's unnumbered book BC151_A2_2_004
A small red notebook containing lists of words and sentences and notes on the |xam language.
Covers and other pages of Lloyd's unnumbered book BC151_A2_2_005
Some Bushman words to be translated (L.C. Lloyd, June, 1913)

A small blue notebook (dated 1913) in which Lloyd lists words and sentences which she took down in Book II-23 (||kabbo) that needed translation. It contains notes to herself and explanations relating to the translation of the terms. There are exact references to lines and pages in the notebook where the terms appear.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Kora Hottentot Book I -1 or MP1
Words and sentences: given by Griet
Griet gives words in her language to Lloyd in Mowbray, mostly concerning parts of the body and animals.
Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

Piet Lynx gives words in his language to Lucy Lloyd in Mowbray, often providing plural and singular declensions. There are sometimes additional columns on the opposite pages, most notably when vocabulary is supplied by Sila, |han=kass'o and Piet Lynx.
The moon said that men should die as it dies. The hare disagreed so the moon struck the hare and split its mouth.
The hare, angry with the moon for wanting men to die as it dies, said that the moon must 'become the Boschvark's shoulder blade bone' and go into the sky 'and make the world light'.
[The Koranna posssess cattle and the Bushmen do not]

A Koranna makes a fire which attracts cattle. He asks the Bushman if he wants the thing that shines or the blackness. The Bushman says 'what shines is mine' and the Koranna says 'mine is the blackness'. When day breaks that which shone is gone and the Bushman appears to leave as if upset ('as if thou wert vexed with me'). This is why the Koranna possess cattle and the Bushmen go without cattle.
Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx
Piet Lynx gives words in his language to Lucy Lloyd. The words cover topography, animals, people, kinds of lizards and more.

A fragmented and partly translated story about hunting, quaggas and the slicing of flesh. Two lions jump upon the original hunters and carry off the flesh. There is a significant break in translation and then "Korhaan Malkop" is talking about carrying a child to fetch water. Eventually two women leave the child with a man and fetch water by themselves, and are berated for doing so. A woman goes back and is killed and eaten. The korhaan and the lions feature again.
Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx
Declensions of various nouns (animals) and pronouns, mostly to do with people and animals.
Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx
Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx
Declensions of various nouns (animals, anatomy, family)
Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx
Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx
Declensions of various nouns (body parts and animals) and verbs.
All came out of one hole

Very little of this story has been translated. 'the living things which move about in the world. all came out of one hole': Kafirs, Englishmen, !koranna, Boers, Bastards, Orlams, Bushmen all 'passed out' (through the hole, presumably). The rest is harder to piece together.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Kora Hottentot Book I -2 or MP2
Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx
Words and sentences about animals, family members, body parts and plants given by Piet Lynx (some at the Museum in Cape Town), with some additional information from !nanni and Tamme.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Kora Hottentot Book I -3 or MP3
A story mostly translated by Louis Maingard about cleverness and the use of it to make a living.
About four rivers in a cave.
Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

Porcupine worked in the clay while Jackal lay on his back playing the goura. When Porcupine had finished working Jackal covered himself in clay 'like one who had worked'. One day Porcupine told the Master who saw Jackal lying on his back. Jackal then said to Porcupine that the master would kill them and that Porcupine must pull out quills so that they might pierce their eyes and jump into the water and die. Porcupine drew out quills and pierced his eyes, while Jackal only put the quills into the corners of his eyes. Then Jackal threw a stone into the water, pretending it was he, and Porcupine jumped in too, and then asked Jackal to help him out. Jackal went to the Master for help and when they got back Porcupine was dead. The master was angry and tried to catch Jackal, but fell into the water and drowned and Jackal became the master. The children of the master grew up and the young master chased Jackal away, so that he lived in the veldt. Jackal and leopard met while leopard was catching fish. Jackal said that Leopard must go into the water and Jackal took the fish that Leopard had caught. Leopard followed his spoor and waited at his home, so Jackal slept in the veldt. Jackal asked why his house did not answer and so it answered "he", and then Jackal asked whether Leopard thought that he was stupid, and went away. He met a lion and said to him that the lion must hold the cliff up while he went to fetch a stick to prop it up. He went away. The leopard came upon the lion while looking for Jackal and said to Lion that the cliff will not fall. The lion pushed at the cliff and fell on his back.
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Kora Hottentot Book I & III-1 or MP4
Words and sentences given by Griet, Piet and Jantje to Isabella Lloyd.
Jemima Bleek's interviews with !nanni and Tamme, September to November 1879
Thirty pages of interviews collected by Jemima Bleek in late 1879 with !nanni (XI) and Tamme (XII). The notebook contains mostly vocabulary, largely relating to animals.

Thirty pages of interviews collected by Jemima Bleek in 1879 with a three 'Hottentot' informants (I, II and III), members of a family ('Lynx') sent to the house in Mowbray in error. The vocabulary mostly concerns parts of the human body, features of the landscape and daily life, and names of animals, and there are some sentences and phrases (most of which were given by 'Piet') concerning times of the day and daily life. There are also snippets of personal history and many examples of communication in Dutch in the course of the interviews.

Notebook on language (words and sentences) of Langeberg Bushmen, met by DB on Mount Temple farm. Some personal details relating to contributors. Most of the words and sentences taken in the book have been written on the numbered right hand pages, with notes & explanations & vocab on the facing verso pages. At the back of the book is a 'Visitors List', dated 1908, with names and addresses written in 2 columns (10pp).

Notebook on language (words and sentences) of Langeberg Bushmen. Some personal details relating to contributors (the Bushmen she met on Mount Temple farm) including names and some genealogical details. Some pages loose. Mostly sentences.
Notebook, preliminary pages unumbered in German script. Words and sentences. Much personal history.

Notebook. Includes some words and sentences. Mostly personal history (genealogies, and places of of contributors and their relations). Customs, especially burial practises. A segment of a diary of DB. Contributions taken from conversations with people at Stuurman's pits, Eyerdoppan etc.
Notebook. Mostly words and sentences. Some personal history (some genealogies). Contributors at same location [?].

Diary. A5 size. DB's journey to Kakia, Bechuanaland. Lots of blank pages. Not paginated by DB but has been paginated by library [1]-[165]. Features comments on journey, settlements, weather, rivers etc, peoples spotted (Masarwa, Bakalaharies etc), the odd little sketch, dictionary work done, photos taken, trading (buying & selling), people measured, artefacts purchased. Report on Lake Chrissie Bushmen.
Notebook. Mostly words and sentences, some personal information. Bechuanaland.
Notebook. Words and sentences and geneaologies, personal history. Bechuanaland.
Reporters' Note Book. Naron language notebook. Words and sentences, some personal history. Reference made to recordings made by DB. Some information regarding customs and daily life.

Reporters' Note Book. Naron language notebook. Short narratives concerning daily life and rituals - especially menstruation, marriage, birth, healing, rain, treatment of bones and hunting; some words and sentences. Photographs mentioned.
Naron & !kun notebook, Vol. I. Words and sentences. Some descriptions of daily life including names and uses of artefacts and relations with others; personal histories.

A manuscript book. !kun or Auen and Naron notebook, volume II. Words and sentences, lots of history of the region (leaders, borders, wars), odd bits of personal history, some local description. Comparisons of daily life and ritual between Naron and !kun, and other groups. Brief narratives describing daily life and ritual eg marriage, living arrangements, artefacts, death.
A manuscript book. Auen and Naron notebook, volume III. Words and sentences, mostly the latter.

A manuscript book. Auen and Naron notebook, volume IV. Words and sentences, mostly the latter. Some interesting descriptions and notes on relations with others, customs and names for things, mention of history of the peoples of the region, cultural practice, markings on the body, birth, death, and so on.

Naron & Auen notebook, Volume IV. Much personal history and of the inhabitants of the area. Considerable detail as to practises and rituals, especially songs and dances and work hunting and looking for veldkos. There are also detailed descriptions of healing rituals, sorcery or doctoring, beliefs about and prayers to the moon, and about ghosts (or ||gauwa). Recordings (ediphones) are mentioned. Much about artefacts made and daily life especially the finding and pursuing of food, making poisons and medicines and what is done with skins.

Naron notebook (volume V) Detailed description of dances, ghosts and spirits, burial of the dead, sorcery and magic arrows, addressing the rain, and related practices. Much personal and local history, names and details about the past and what the old people used to teach. References to recordings. Descriptions of hunting and cooking, arrow-making, cutting and healing, trading, smoking and eating, male and female practises, songs & different types of dances. Mention of creatures/beings/spirits and gives their names and beliefs related to them (||gauwa, |gone, !xuba, Hisesha).

Naron notebook (volume VII). Descriptions of daily life, contemporary life and personal history. Much about sorcery (doctors and old people), healing, cutting practises, games (eg the 'war game'), dancing and magic animals (such as baboons and lions); artefacts and dress, food hunted and eaten, relations with inhabitants of the region; marriage, birth, name-giving and other family life; and naming stars and asking stars for food, as well as rain and related animals such as the mantis. References to the coming of Christianity and associated beliefs.

Auen notebook, volume VIII. Much description of daily life, current life and personl history, including relations with others and the inhabitants of the area/settlement. There are interesting descriptions of dancing, sorcery, healing and magic animals, as well as practises relating to death and marriage and family life. There is much given relating to hunting, cooking, eating and finding food, as well as the coming of Christianity to the people and associated beliefs. There are also many names and descriptions of artefacts such as weapons, instruments and ornaments and dress.

Naron notebook, Vol. IX? (with Auen contributions too). Fairly fragmented accounts of contemporary life, history and building of the settlement, and personal history; much daily life, including illness, names of plants and animals, rain and seasons and food, fire, habits of animals, and burial practises and family life. Some interesting descriptions of using buchu to say 'goodbye' to the dead. Mostly in the form of words and sentences with some scattered narrative.

Notes made in Angola[?], 1925. Originally a visitor's book (pre-1918) and includes signatures of numerous well-known people (first 64 pages). A scrap of paper written by the library says !O !kun. Words and sentences and brief genealogies with names of people and their relations. Brief references to daily life of the people interviewed. Some of the clicks are different, for example what resembles an elongated 'S' [what I have as ].

Notes made in Angola, 1925. 5 inserts and maps. A dense notebook containing words and sentences with large amount of personal history, names of relations, descriptions of ways of life of Bushmen and others, history of the region and its inhabitants, and things from daily life, includes mention of illness, a lot about spirits, death, sorcery and burial practises. A library note in the notebook says 'Angolan !kung'.

Notes made in Angola 1925. Words and sentences and personal history and history of the inhabitants of the area, and descriptions of objects and actions from daily life, as well as fragments relating to markings, and songs and dances. Most of the book is blank p.205-213.

Notes on rock paintings in caves in the Orange Free State c.1928, including comments on condition of the paintings, location of the caves and comparision between Stow's copies and originals. Also some fragments of stories and some words.

Notes on rock paintings in caves in the Orange Free State c.1928, including comments on the condition of the paintings, the location of the caves and comparisions between Stow's copies and originals, as well as notes as to paintings to be copied in the future.

Notes on rock paintings copied by Stow, and revisited by DB, mainly in the Eastern Cape near Queenstown. Notes about other paintings discovered as well as the farms they are found on and who to ask for directions. No pagination. Reference to 'Films' or photographs taken [?].

Record of D Bleek's visit to the Hadza of Tanganyika, 1930. Words and sentences with very fragmented narratives towards the latter half of the book. Also some names and descriptions of personal history and of the region, and comments about things that Bushmen do (such as taking a wife, and burial) and eat, especially according to the seasons; some fragments of what seem to be myths. Loose inserts, words and maps.

Record of D Bleek's visit to the Hadza of Tanganyika, 1930. Words and sentences and fragmented narratives towards the latter half of the book. Also many descriptions of personal history and rough genealogical diagrams, and comments about things that Bushmen do and eat, especially cutting and tattooing by doctors when people are ill.

Notes on |auni, Vol.1, made at Frankenwald Research Station, Witwatersrand University. Words and sentences and much personal history. Also some fragmented information about artefacts, ornaments and daily life, markings (cuts made for hunting and the cutting of girls for example).

Notes on |auni Vol.2, made at Frankenwald Research Station, Witwatersrand University (presumably, it doesn't say so in the notebook). Words and sentences and personal history, including some rough genealogies. Also some fragmented information relating to daily life including hunting, taking a wife, making huts, 'curing', and artefacts, as well as the 'retirement' of menstruating girls in huts. The final unnumbered pages of the notebook have been left blank.

A dictionary, A-Z. Language unknown, but likely to be Mbunela, as there is a reference to the Mbunela language in the notebook. The notebook also contains grammar in same language: pronouns, alphabet, tenses, prefixes and verbs, 'Capula' [?], pronouns, numerals, demonstratives, adjectives. Most of the pages in the second half of the notebook are blank, except for the odd note, address and bit of language (others) recorded, drawing of river and part of an intinerary, objects and 'Miss Wilman', as well as some names of people 2 pages from the back.

Bushman genealogies, undated. Some brief descriptions and personal histories, such as where individuals worked, came from, who they married, how many children they had and so on. Information about different groups such as the 'Vaalpens'. Names of people according to huts they occupy (10 of them), also some numbers next to their names.
